questions.text: Identify the urinary crystal shown below? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcium oxalate


Calcium oxalate crystals are typically bipyramidal or envelope-shaped. These crystals are common in various conditions, including hyperoxaluria and ethylene glycol poisoning.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Calcium phosphate:  crystals form asymmetric rosettes.

 

Option C. Uric acid:  crystals are rhomboid forming rosettes, polychromatophilic in Polarized Microscope.

 

Option D. Cystine:  crystals are hexagonal, and one of the hardest crystals.

 

Note - Monohydrate crystal – dumbbell shaped

 

Educational Objective:

 

Calcium oxalate crystals are bipyramidal or envelope-shaped.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented with symptoms of inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th and 5th digits. He was also not able to hold a piece of paper between his fingers. What is the likely site of injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. C

 

Explanation:

 

An ulnar nerve damage is suggested by the clinical scenario, which includes a positive card test and the inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th and 5th digits.

 

The most likely site of injury would thus be medial epicondyle: site C

 

 

Damage to the ulnar nerve at the medial epicondyle causes paralysis of the flexor carpi ulnaris (lack of ulnar deviation) and the medial half of the flexor digitorum profundus (loss of distal interphalangeal joint flexion). Hypothenar paralysis (which causes atrophy) and sensory loss are the results. Moreover, the extensor digitorum and flexor digitorum superficialis (provided by the radial nerve and median nerve, respectively) continue to function. The third and fourth digits are therefore not completely paralysed. The palmar interossei's fragility, which causes a loss of adduction, is what causes the positive card test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Head of the Humerus: Articulates with the shoulder joint. Injury here typically affects shoulder movement, not the distal functions like finger flexion or sensory issues associated with the ulnar nerve.

 

Option B. Intertubercular Groove: Houses the tendon of the biceps brachii. Mainly affects movements related to the biceps muscle, not ulnar nerve functions.

 

Option D. Lateral Epicondyle: Attachment site for forearm extensor muscles. Primarily involved in conditions like lateral epicondylitis, which causes localized pain rather than the broader sensory and motor deficits seen in ulnar nerve damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulnar nerve branches and supply:

 

 

Superficial branch supplies palmaris brevis, skin on the palmar surface of medial 1½ fingers. The deep branch runs within the concavity of deep palmar arch and supplies all intrinsic muscles of the hand (except first 2 lumbricals and thenar muscles).

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a male patient in his early twenties who presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of abdominal pain and obstipation, and reports blunt injury to the abdomen 3 days prior? The provided X-ray image may provide clues to the diagnosis: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hollow viscus perforation

 

  • The given radiograph in the erect position indicates air under the diaphragm, which is a typical finding in cases of hollow viscus perforation.
  • A history of trauma, accompanied by symptoms of abdominal pain and obstipation, supports the diagnosis of a perforation of the alimentary tract.

 

A perforation of a hollow organ (like the intestines or stomach) can lead to air and contents of the organ leaking into the abdominal cavity. It can be a result of trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemothorax: This condition is characterized by the accumulation of blood within the pleural cavity, often due to trauma. The patient's symptoms are abdominal in nature and not respiratory, making this an unlikely diagnosis. Hemothorax would be evident on a chest X-ray.

 

Option C. Pneumothorax: This is the presence of air in the pleural cavity, often due to trauma or a spontaneous event, leading to lung collapse. Similar to hemothorax, this condition is related to the respiratory system and would not be the cause of abdominal pain or obstipation.

 

Option D. Intestinal obstruction: This condition involves a blockage that prevents the contents of the intestines from passing normally through the digestive tract. However, no free air should be seen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hollow viscus perforation can cause acute bacterial peritonitis, which is inflammation of the peritoneum that can be localized or generalized.
  • Clinical features of peritonitis include abdominal pain that worsens with movement, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, and guarding on palpation. Fever may also be present, and septic shock can occur in later stages.
  • An erect abdominal radiograph that shows free gas under the diaphragm.
  • Management of peritonitis involves general care of the patient in terms of nutritional support and pain relief. Laparotomy and surgical treatment of the cause is usually necessary.

questions.text: All of the following increases gastric acid secretion except: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serotonin

 

Explanation

 

All of the options listed increase gastric acid secretion except serotonin.

 

Gastric Acid Secretion:

 

  • Parietal Cells: Located deep in the oxyntic glands of the main body of the stomach, parietal cells are the only cells that secrete hydrochloric acid (HCl).
  • Enterochromaffin-Like (ECL) Cells: These cells lie in the deep recesses of the oxyntic glands and release histamine in direct contact with the parietal cells of the glands. The rate of HCl formation and secretion by the parietal cells is directly related to the amount of histamine secreted by the ECL cells.

 

Stimulation of ECL Cells:

 

  1. Gastrin: The most potent stimulator of histamine secretion from ECL cells.
  2. Acetylcholine: Released from stomach vagal nerve endings, stimulates ECL cells.
  3. Histamine: Released by ECL cells, directly stimulates parietal cells to secrete HCl.

 

Role of Serotonin:

 

  • Serotonin: Localized in the enterochromaffin cells of the gastrointestinal (GI) mucosa and within neurons of the GI tract, serotonin inhibits gastric acid secretion. It also stimulates the production and release of gastric and colonic mucus. Serotonin acts as an enteric neurotransmitter and increases intestinal motility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrin: Incorrect. Gastrin increases gastric acid secretion.

 

Option B. Histamine: Incorrect. Histamine increases gastric acid secretion.

 

Option C. Acetylcholine: Incorrect. Acetylcholine increases gastric acid secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serotonin inhibits gastric acid secretion, while gastrin, histamine, and acetylcholine stimulate it. Serotonin also stimulates mucus production and increases intestinal motility, acting as an enteric neurotransmitter.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in this image? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ascaris lumbricoides

 

The roundworm, Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine.

 

They are large cylindrical worms with tapered ends.

 

The anterior end is more pointed than the posterior.

 

They are pale pink or flesh coloured when freshly passed in stools, but become white outside the body.

 

The mouth at the anterior end has three finely toothed lips, one dorsal and two ventrolateral

 

Habitat - Small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum).

 

Natural host – Man

 

Infective form – embryonated eggs containing infective rhabditiform larvae

 

Mode of transmission – feco-oral route

 

Disease caused by A. lumbricoides is called as ascariasis.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Strongyloides stercoralis: This nematode causes strongyloidiasis and is much smaller and thread-like in appearance compared to Ascaris lumbricoides.

 

Option B. Enterobius vermicularis: Commonly known as pinworm, this parasite is much smaller and thinner than Ascaris lumbricoides and is primarily found in the colon and rectum.

 

Option C. Ancylostoma duodenale: This is a hookworm that has a different morphology with a characteristic curved anterior end, and it primarily inhabits the small intestine where it attaches to the mucosa.

 

Educational Objective

 

Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine, identifiable by its large size, cylindrical shape with tapered ends, and characteristic mouth with three finely toothed lips.

choices.text: rk 39 antigen test, Leishmaniasis
pLDH, Plasmodium malaria
Biopsy, Histoplasmosis
ELISA, HIV

questions.text: A man with FUO has a job that requires traveling around the world. The bone marrow picture is shown below. Which of the following investigation would be the most appropriate in this case? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) rk 39 antigen test, Leishmaniasis

 

This given clinical picture shows A and B. macrophage infested with intracellular Leishmania donovani bodies (arrows) characterized by a kinetoplast and characteristic double dot appearance (Leishman stain) suggestive of Leishmaniasis which can be confirmed by the rk 39 antigen test.

 

There are 3 main forms of leishmaniases: visceral (the most serious form because it is almost always fatal without treatment), cutaneous (the most common, usually causing skin ulcers), and mucocutaneous (affecting mouth, nose and throat).

 

Leishmaniasis is caused by protozoan parasites which are transmitted by the bite of infected female phlebotomine sandflies.

 

Following the discovery of a 39-amino acid residue (k-39) encoded by a kinesin-related gene in the amastigotes of Leishmania chagasi, it has been used in the format of enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). 

 

Immunochromatographic test (ICT) for detection of antibodies with high sensitivity and specificity.1,4–6 Anti-k39 antibodies are secreted into various body fluids such as urine and sputum along with blood, and have been shown to be useful in the diagnosis of Visceral leishmaniasis (VL). rK39 strip test is rapid and a sensitive and specific indicator of visceral leishmaniasis(VL).

 

Parasitological methods of diagnosis remain the gold standard for diagnosing leishmaniasis. Diagnosis in the laboratory can be achieved by direct examination of amastigotes in giemsa-stained lesion smears of scrapping, biopsies, or impression smears.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. pLDH, Plasmodium malaria: Plasmodium malaria would present differently on a blood smear and would not typically show macrophages with intracellular organisms in a bone marrow sample. The pLDH test is specific for diagnosing malaria, not leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Biopsy, Histoplasmosis: Histoplasmosis could cause fever of unknown origin and show organisms in macrophages, but the morphology would be different from Leishmania donovani. Histoplasma typically appears as small yeast forms within macrophages, not the double dot appearance seen here.

 

Option D. ELISA, HIV: While HIV can present with fever of unknown origin, it would not directly explain the bone marrow findings of intracellular Leishmania bodies. An ELISA test for HIV is not relevant to diagnosing the cause of the observed bone marrow pathology.

 

Educational Objective

 

The presence of macrophages with intracellular Leishmania donovani bodies in the bone marrow is diagnostic for leishmaniasis. The rk 39 antigen test is a rapid and reliable method for confirming visceral leishmaniasis.

questions.text: Methyl tetrahydrofolate accumulation and functional deficiency of folate is seen in the deficiency of: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vit B12

 

Vitamin B12, also known as cobalamin, is essential for DNA synthesis and plays a role in the conversion of methyl tetrahydrofolate to its active form. Deficiency of vitamin B12 can lead to the functional deficiency of folate because it impairs the regeneration of tetrahydrofolate from methyl tetrahydrofolate, leading to the accumulation of the latter.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folic acid: Folic acid, also known as vitamin B9, is a crucial vitamin required for DNA synthesis, cell division, and various metabolic processes. In cases of folic acid deficiency, methyl tetrahydrofolate can accumulate, but there is no direct deficiency of vitamin B12. Folic acid deficiency primarily affects folate-dependent reactions.

 

Option C. Vit B1: Vitamin B1, also known as thiamine, is not directly related to the metabolism of folate or methyl tetrahydrofolate. It primarily plays a role in carbohydrate metabolism as a cofactor for enzymes involved in the citric acid cycle.

 

Option D. Vit B6: Vitamin B6, also known as pyridoxine, is involved in various enzymatic reactions, including those related to amino acid metabolism. It is not directly associated with the metabolism of folate or methyl tetrahydrofolate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the metabolic consequences of vitamin deficiencies, medical students should recognize that the functional deficiency of folate, characterized by the accumulation of methyl tetrahydrofolate, is primarily seen in vitamin B12 deficiency, making it important to distinguish between the two deficiencies in clinical practice.

 

Deficiency of Vitamin B12 leads to accumulation of methyl THF. Free THF becomes deficient (Folate Trap) and as THF is functional form of folate it is also known as functional deficiency of folate.

 

 

Ref - Harper 31st e/p 536

questions.text: In conventional oxygen therapy, which device will deliver the highest FiO2? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-rebreathing mask

 

  • FiO2 Delivery: A non-rebreathing mask can deliver an FiO2 of up to 80% at flow rates of 10-15 L/min. This mask has a reservoir bag that fills with oxygen and a one-way valve that prevents the exhaled air from entering the reservoir bag, ensuring a higher concentration of oxygen is inhaled.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venturi mask: The Venturi mask delivers a precise FiO2, which can range from 24% to 66%, depending on the entrainment device used. It is often used in patients who require a specific oxygen concentration.

 

Option B. Hudson mask: This option appears to refer to a simple face mask, which can deliver up to 60% FiO2 at 10 L/min. It is less efficient in delivering high concentrations of oxygen compared to a non-rebreathing mask.

 

Option D. Nasal cannula: A nasal cannula typically delivers up to 44% FiO2 at a flow rate of 6 L/min. It is comfortable and used for patients who need low to moderate oxygen supplementation but cannot deliver the high concentrations achievable with a non-rebreathing mask.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The non-rebreathing mask delivers the highest FiO2 in conventional oxygen therapy, capable of providing up to 80% FiO2 at flow rates of 10-15 L/min, making it suitable for patients requiring high concentrations of oxygen.

choices.text: Downregulation of CYP2C19
Downregulation of CYP2D6
Upregulation of CYP1A1
Downregulation of CYP2E1

questions.text: A patient of 45 year with history of ischemic stroke was started on clopidogrel, However, she had another attack of stroke after 6 months. Which of the following is likely to be responsible for the failure of clopidogrel in this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Downregulation of CYP2C19


Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet drug used to prevent MI and stroke. The failure of clopidogrel in preventing a second stroke in a patient can be influenced by various factors, including genetic variations that affect drug metabolism.

 

Clopidogrel is a prodrug that requires activation by CYP2C19. Genetic polymorphisms or downregulation of CYP2C19 can lead to reduced conversion of clopidogrel to its active form. This results in decreased antiplatelet activity and a higher risk of thrombotic events, such as stroke. Individuals with reduced function alleles of CYP2C19 are known as "poor metabolizers," and in these patients, clopidogrel may be less effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Downregulation of CYP2D6: While CYP2D6 is important for the metabolism of many drugs, it is not primarily responsible for the activation of clopidogrel. Therefore, downregulation of CYP2D6 would not significantly impact clopidogrel's effectiveness.

 

Option C. Upregulation of CYP1A1: CYP1A1 is not involved in the metabolism of clopidogrel. Its upregulation would not affect the activation of clopidogrel or its therapeutic efficacy.

 

Option D. Downregulation of CYP2E1: CYP2E1 is involved in the metabolism of ethanol and certain other drugs but does not play a significant role in the activation of clopidogrel. Therefore, downregulation of CYP2E1 would not impact clopidogrel's effectiveness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The failure of clopidogrel in preventing a second stroke in a patient may be due to the downregulation of CYP2C19. This enzyme is crucial for converting clopidogrel into its active form, and its reduced activity can lead to decreased antiplatelet effects and increased risk of thrombotic events.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1

 

Explanation:

 

Let's match the descriptions to the terms:

 

A. Depression : "Difficult to diagnose due to the shell of physician’s pride" would suggest that physicians might not show or express their symptoms due to professional pride. So, A matches with 3.

 

B. Suicide : "Women physicians, substance abuse, relationship troubles" could be potential risk factors or associated factors. So, B matches with 4.

 

C. Burnout : "State of emotional and physical exhaustion caused by prolonged stress, relieved after relaxation" perfectly describes burnout. So, C matches with 2.

 

D. Overthinking : "The feeling goes away as soon as you leave the hospital" does not clearly correlate with overthinking, but given the other matches, this seems the closest fit. So, D matches with 1.

 

So, the correct matching would be:

 

A) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 447, 764.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy was brought to the casualty with seizures. The pediatrician tries to do CSF sampling. What are the structures punctured by the pediatrician while piercing through the marked structure? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Scalp, dura, arachnoid

 

Explanation:

 

The arrow in the illustration, which displays a baby's skull, is pointing in the direction of the anterior fontanelle. Ventricular tapping is the term used to describe the process of removing CSF from the anterior fontanelle. The various structures pierced are the scalp, dura, and arachnoid.

 

Fontanelle tap/ Percutaneous ventricular puncture:

 

Infants who need urgent ventricular decompression and have an open anterior fontanelle and no access to a VP shunt undergo a fontanelle tap or percutaneous ventricular puncture. A butterfly needle is used to immediately puncture the infant's open fontanelle and enter the lateral ventricle in order to obtain CS samples, alleviate pressure, or insert a drain or catheter.

 

Procedure: A 25-gauge butterfly needle is inserted through the anterolateral aspect of the anterior fontanelle (away from the midline, avoiding the superior sagittal sinus).

 

When performing a fontanelle tap, the following layers are pierced:

 

  • Scalp: This includes the skin and the underlying connective tissue of the scalp.
  • Membranous fontanelle: The actual fontanelle is a soft spot on a baby's head where the bones of the skull have not yet fused together. It's a membranous gap between the cranial bones.
  • Dura mater: The tough outermost membrane of the three layers of the meninges that surround the brain and spinal cord.
  • Arachnoid mater: A thin, wispy layer that lies underneath the dura mater.
  • Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF): Once through the arachanoid mater, the needle enters the subarachnoid space where the CSF is located.

 

Note: The fontanelle tap bypasses the bony skull, which is why it's an accessible route in neonates and infants for procedures that require access to the CSF. However, as the child grows, these fontanelles close, and the method is no longer viable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fontanelle tap is a critical emergency procedure used in infants for CSF sampling or pressure relief from the ventricles, exploiting the unossified sections of the skull for direct access to the CSF. This procedure is unique to neonates and young infants where the fontanelle is present and typically involves piercing the scalp, dura, and arachnoid layers.

questions.text: At the Urban Primary Health Centre (U-PHC), you are in charge of managing hypertension clinic services. You have 50 patients transferred from another healthcare unit for hypertension management; 40 of these patients are prescribed amlodipine (5mg, daily) and 10 are on lisinopril (10mg, daily) due to contraindications with amlodipine. Considering the need for continuous treatment and potential increases in patient numbers, calculate the number of tablets needed for the next month and determine the appropriate reorder factor. (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3000, rf=2

 

Calculation -  

 

Requirement of Amlodipine

 

40 patients x 1 Tablet per day x 30 Days = 1200 Tablets

 

Requirement of Lisinopril

 

10 patients x 1 Tablet per day x 30 Days = 300 Tablets

 

Reorder factor (Rf) for drugs supplied every:

 

  • 1 Month - 2
  • 3 Months - 6
  • 6 Months – 12

 

For the given question,

 

Total of 1500 tablets are required and reorder factor is 2

 

Hence, Total tablets required = (1200 + 300) x 2 = 3000 Tablets

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Reorder Factor (rf): A reorder factor of 2 is commonly used for monthly resupply scenarios to account for unexpected increases in patient count or dosage adjustments, ensuring no interruption in patient care.

questions.text: Which of the following sensory receptors are responsible for tactile discrimination? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Meissner's corpuscle

 

Meissner's Corpuscles are responsible for discriminative touch.

 

 

Meissner’s corpuscle

 

Touch receptor with great sensitivity

An elongated encapsulated nerve ending of a large (type AB. myelinated sensory nerve fiber. Inside the capsulation are many branching terminal nerve filaments.

 

Present in the non-hairy parts of the skin and are particularly abundant in the fingertips, lips, and other areas of the skin where one’s ability to discern spatial locations of touch sensations is highly developed.

 

These are responsible for

 

  • Point discrimination
  • Precise location
  • Tapping
  • Flutter

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Merkel Disc: Allows one to determine continuous touch of objects against the skin.

 

Option B. Ruffini End Organ: Responsible for temperature sensation.

 

Option C. Pacinian Corpuscle: Responsible for pressure and crude touch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meissner's corpuscles are specialized for discriminative touch, enabling precise location and detection of fine tactile stimuli. They are most abundant in areas where tactile acuity is high, such as the fingertips and lips

questions.text: Identify the pathology from the given flow-volume loop: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fixed central airway obstruction


The flow-volume loop shows flattening of both the inspiratory and expiratory limbs, which is characteristic of a fixed central airway obstruction. This pattern suggests an obstruction that affects airflow both during inhalation and exhalation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fixed distal airway obstruction would not typically affect both phases of the loop.

 

Option C. Variable intrathoracic obstruction affects the expiratory phase more.

 

Option D. Variable extrathoracic obstruction affects the inspiratory phase more.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flattening of both inspiratory and expiratory limbs in a flow-volume loop indicates a fixed central airway obstruction.

questions.text:
What is the correct sequence of cellular events of inflammation? (AIIMS MAY 2021)

 

  1. Rolling
  2. Cytokine mediated integrin activation
  3. Adhesion
  4. Migration
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Correct sequence of events during inflammation:

 

  1. Rolling
  2. Cytokine mediated integrin activation
  3. Adhesion
  4. Migration

 

CELLULAR CHANGES DURING INFLAMMATION

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of intravascular cellular events during inflammation involves rolling, cytokine-mediated integrin activation, adhesion, and migration.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 10th edition pg. 78-79

questions.text: The formula for urea clearance is U*V/P, where U is?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urine urea in mg /100ml

 

'U' in the urea clearance stands for urine concentration of urea in mg /100ml.

 

The formula for renal clearance of a substance is,

 

Clearance (C = U × V / P),

 

  • U = Urine concentration of the substance in mg / ml
  • V = Urine flow rate in ml/min
  • P = Plasma concentration of substance in mg /ml.

 

Renal clearance of a substance is the volume of plasma that is completely cleared of the substance by the kidneys per unit of time.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: About 20-30% of the infections are symptomatic
Triad of SNHL, periventricular calcification and enamel hypoplasia
Most children asymptomatic at birth can develop conductive hearing loss later in life
If mother is IgG positive for CMV, the child is unlikely to develop infection

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about congenital CMV infection? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) If mother is IgG positive for CMV, the child is unlikely to develop infection

 

Congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection is a significant cause of congenital infection and can lead to a range of outcomes in the fetus, depending on the timing and nature of maternal infection. If a mother is IgG positive for CMV, it indicates a past infection and a lower risk of transmitting the virus to the fetus compared to a primary infection. This is because maternal IgG antibodies can provide some protection to the fetus. However, there remains a small risk of reactivation of the virus or reinfection during pregnancy, which could lead to congenital CMV infection in the fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. About 20-30% of the infections are symptomatic: About 20-30% of the infections are symptomatic is incorrect because the correct percentage of symptomatic congenital CMV infections at birth is about 10%, not 20-30%.

 

Option B. Triad of SNHL, periventricular calcification and enamel hypoplasia: Triad of SNHL, periventricular calcification and enamel hypoplasia is incorrect because enamel hypoplasia is not a typical part of the triad for congenital CMV infection. The common findings include SNHL, periventricular calcifications, and developmental delays.

 

Option C. Most children asymptomatic at birth can develop conductive hearing loss later in life: Most children asymptomatic at birth can develop conductive hearing loss later in life is incorrect because asymptomatic infants at birth are less likely to develop hearing loss, and if they do, it is usually sensorineural, not conductive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maternal IgG positivity for CMV suggests a lower risk of congenital CMV transmission, making it less likely for the fetus to develop the infection.

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of minor trauma 20 days back with a piece of wood. He presented as shown in the image. CT scan revealed clear sinuses and the presence of subcutaneous nodules. Microscopy of the tissue sections are positive to PAS and positive on Gomori methamine silver stain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phycomycosis

 

The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Phycomycosis /Mucormycosis.

 

It is fungal infection of nose and paranasal sinuses which may prove rapidly fatal. It is seen in uncontrolled diabetics or in those taking immunosuppressive drugs.

 

PATHOLOGY – From the nose and sinuses, infection can spread to orbit, cribriform plate, meninges and brain. The rapid destruction associated with the disease is due to affinity of the fungus to invade the arteries and cause endothelial damage and thrombosis.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES – Black necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate.

 

DIAGNOSIS – Special stains help to identify the fungus in tissue sections.

 

Black turbinate sign is seen on contrast MRI.

 

TREATMENT – Amphotericin B and surgical debridement of the affected tissues and control of underlying predisposing cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midline lethal granuloma: Primarily involves destructive lesions of the midline facial structures but lacks the fungal component.

 

Option B. Foreign body granuloma: Typically arises from a reaction to a foreign material but would not cause the extensive symptoms or be positive on the fungal stains used.

 

Option D. IgG4 granuloma: Associated with elevated levels of IgG4 and typically presents with tumefactive lesions, not primarily infectious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phycomycosis is a serious fungal infection affecting mainly the nasal passages and sinuses, identifiable by special staining techniques and known for its aggressive, potentially fatal progression requiring prompt treatment with antifungals and surgery.

choices.text: Adequate safety profile needs to be established
Cost to benefit has to be considered
Fixed dose combination of drugs is preferred over single drugs

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the selection of essential drugs? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Fixed dose combination of drugs is preferred over single drugs

 

The WHO has defined Essential Medicines (Drugs) as “those that satisfy the priority healthcare needs of the population. They are selected with due regard to public health relevance, evidence on efficacy and safety, and comparative cost effectiveness. Essential medicines are intended to be available within the context of functioning health systems at all times and in adequate amounts, in appropriate dosage forms, with assured quality and adequate information, and at a price the individual and the community can afford.”

 

This is generally false. While fixed-dose combinations (FDCs) can be beneficial in certain scenarios (like in the treatment of HIV/AIDS or tuberculosis), they are not universally preferred over single-drug formulations. The preference for FDCs or single drugs depends on several factors, including the therapeutic context, the risk of drug-drug interactions, patient adherence, and the potential for resistance development. Mostly, single drugs are preferred due to their flexibility in dosing and the ability to adjust individual components based on patient needs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adequate safety profile needs to be established: This is true. When selecting essential drugs, it's crucial that they have a well-established safety profile. Safety is a key consideration to ensure that the benefits of a drug outweigh its risks.

 

Option B. Cost to benefit has to be considered: This is also true. In the selection of essential drugs, the cost-effectiveness of a drug is an important factor. The aim is to provide the most effective treatment at the lowest possible cost.

 

Option D. Disease prevalence is considered: This is true. When selecting essential drugs, the prevalence of diseases in a population is an important consideration. Drugs to treat common and life-threatening diseases are typically prioritized.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The selection of essential drugs prioritizes factors like safety, cost-effectiveness, and disease prevalence. Fixed-dose combinations are not universally preferred over single drugs, as the choice depends on specific therapeutic needs and other considerations.

choices.text: Increase flow rate to 15 L/min
High-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who was under home isolation after testing positive for COVID-19, develops breathing difficulty and is brought to the ER. The patient is alert and responsive, but his respiratory rate is 26/min. Room air Sp02 is 86%. He is administered oxygen through a non -rebreathing mask with a flow rate of 10 L/ min. After a trial of one hour, his SpO2 is 88%. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy

 

  • Mechanism of Action: HFNC can deliver warmed, humidified oxygen at high flow rates (up to 60 L/min or more), creating a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) effect, reducing nasopharyngeal dead space, and improving oxygenation.
  • Effectiveness: Studies have shown its effectiveness in treating acute hypoxemic respiratory failure in COVID-19 patients. Given that the patient's SpO2 didn't improve significantly with an NRB, transitioning to HFNC might be a logical step before considering more invasive measures like intubation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase flow rate to 15 L/min: The non-rebreather mask (NRB) is designed to deliver high concentrations of oxygen (up to 90%). Increasing the flow rate may slightly improve the fraction of delivered oxygen, but it may not result in significant improvement in oxygenation, especially if the cause of hypoxia isn't just a low FiO2. Therefore, merely increasing the flow rate may not be sufficient to address the patient's respiratory distress.

 

Option C. Endotracheal intubation: Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation are invasive interventions, reserved for patients who are in respiratory failure and cannot maintain adequate oxygenation and/or ventilation with less invasive means. While this patient is hypoxic, jumping straight to intubation without trialing intermediate steps like HFNC might be premature, especially since the patient is alert and responsive.

 

Option D. No specific intervention necessary: Given the patient's low SpO2 and increased respiratory rate, no intervention is not an appropriate choice. The patient is in respiratory distress and requires further measures to improve his oxygenation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with COVID-19 and hypoxemia unresponsive to a non-rebreather mask, transitioning to high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy (HFNC) is a logical next step. HFNC can provide better oxygenation and is a less invasive option before considering endotracheal intubation.

questions.text: By which cell of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma arises? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Naive B cells

 

The cell of origin of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL)/ Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (SLL) is either naïve B cells or post-germinal centre memory B cell.

 

 

 

FCL = Follicular Cell Lymphoma; MALT = Marginal Zone Lymphoma of Mucosa-Associated Lymphoid Tissue; MCL = Mantle Cell Lymphoma; SLL/CLL = Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma/Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mature B cells: While mature B cells can give rise to certain types of lymphomas, CLL/SLL specifically arises from naive B cells or post-germinal center memory B cells.

 

Option B. Mature T cells: Mature T cells are associated with different types of lymphomas, such as T-cell lymphomas, not CLL/SLL.

 

Option C. Progenitor T cells: Progenitor T cells are involved in the development of T-cell leukemias and lymphomas, such as T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia, not CLL/SLL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma arises from naive B cells or post-germinal center memory B cells, distinguishing it from other B-cell and T-cell malignancies.

questions.text: Identify the type of physical restraint given in the picture below: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hog tie

 

This type of physical restraint is called Hog tying. The method involves restraining a prisoner's hands behind his back, restraining his feet and then coupling the hand and feet restraints from the back.

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Choke/carotid hold: A choke hold is a grappling hold that critically reduces or prevents either air or blood from passing through the neck of an opponent. It is commonly used in martial arts and law enforcement but is not shown in the image.

 

Option B: Carotid sleeper hold: This hold is a type of choke hold that targets the carotid arteries to induce unconsciousness. It is also used in self-defence and law enforcement but does not match the restraint method shown in the image.

 

Option D: Bar arm: A bar arm restraint involves using the arm to apply pressure to the neck or back, typically in law enforcement. It does not match the method of tying hands and feet together as seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective

 

Hog tying involves restraining a person’s hands behind their back, restraining their feet, and coupling the hand and feet restraints together from behind, often used as a form of torture or control.

 

Additional Information

 

Torture

 

  1. Wet submarino/ Latina  – suffocation of head in liquids/ dirty liquids

 

  1. Dry submarino: Plastic bag around face

 

  1. Telefono – beating on ear by hands

 

  1. Falanga (Bastinado): Beating on feet

 

  1. Parrot’s perch – rod placed below knees , upside down , hands tied to rod



 

6. Planton – person made to stand for long hours

             

7. Saw horse – victim sits on sharp object → injury to perineal area

 

 

8. Hog tie – Restraining a prisoner's hands behind his back, restraining his feet and then coupling the hand and feet restraints from the back.

 

9. Ghotna – wooden log rolled over the legs

 

10. Chepuwa – wooden log is compressed on legs

 

11. Black slave – hot metal rod in anus

 

12. Electric cattle prod – electric current to sensitive parts (nipple, genitalia)

questions.text:
In a PHC, which of the following initial screening tests are used to diagnose diabetes? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. HbA1c >6.5
  2. Fasting blood sugar >126 mg/dL
  3. Random blood sugar >200 mg/dL
  4. 2-hour post glucose load blood sugar
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3

 

The initial screening tests for diagnosing diabetes in a primary health care setting generally include the following criteria:

 

2. Fasting blood sugar >126 mg/dL: A fasting blood glucose level of 126 mg/dL or higher on two separate occasions indicates diabetes. Fasting is defined as no caloric intake for at least 8 hours.

 

3. Random blood sugar >200 mg/dL: A random blood glucose level of 200 mg/dL or higher, along with symptoms of diabetes, is sufficient for diagnosis. This test does not require fasting and can be taken at any time.

 

Other Options:

 

1. HbA1c >6.5%: While this test is beneficial for its ability to reflect average blood glucose levels over the past two to three months and does not require fasting, its higher cost and need for more sophisticated laboratory equipment make it less likely to be used at PHCs in India.

 

4. 2-hour post glucose load blood sugar: Part of the Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT), this test is more comprehensive but requires more time and resources, which may not be feasible in all primary care settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial screening tests for diagnosing diabetes in a primary health care (PHC) setting typically include fasting blood sugar >126 mg/dL, and random blood sugar >200 mg/dL. These tests are widely accepted and feasible in most PHC settings.

questions.text:
A pediatrician is reviewing mortality trends among children aged between 1-4 years based on verbal autopsy reports from the years 2010-2013. She wants to educate parents on the primary causes of death to improve preventive measures in her community. From the list provided below, which sequence correctly represents the leading causes of death in a descending order for this age group? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Diarrhea
  2. Pneumonia
  3. Malaria
  4. Injuries
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2>1>4>3

 

  • According to the verbal autopsy report of 2010-2013, leading cause of death among 1–4-year-old children in a developing country like India in descending order is Pneumonia > Diarrhea > Injuries > Malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 In a developed country, leading causes of death are:

 

  1. Accident injury
  2. Congenital anomaly
  3. Neoplasms
  4. Influenza
  5. Pneumonia

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain. An abdominal ultrasound reveals the presence of multiple gallstones with no evidence of wall thickening. The bile duct (BD) diameter is measured at 12 mm, and serum bilirubin levels are mildly elevated at 0.8. The patient's alkaline phosphatase levels are significantly elevated at 380, and the gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) levels are raised by 5 times. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MRCP

 

Given the patient's presentation of multiple gallstones, an enlarged bile duct diameter, and elevated liver enzymes, there is a high suspicion of choledocholithiasis (stones in the common bile duct). An MRCP is the most appropriate initial investigation to visualize and confirm the presence of common bile duct stones without subjecting the patient to an invasive procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography): ERCP is an invasive procedure that allows both the visualization and treatment of biliary and pancreatic duct abnormalities. While it can be used to diagnose and treat choledocholithiasis, it is generally reserved for therapeutic interventions after the diagnosis has been established, given the risks associated with the procedure.

 

Option C. Endoscopic ultrasound: This technique can be very sensitive for detecting common bile duct stones and other biliary pathologies. However, in the context of a patient with an enlarged bile duct and elevated liver enzymes suggestive of choledocholithiasis, MRCP would be the preferred initial diagnostic tool.

 

Option D. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy: While the patient may ultimately require a cholecystectomy, especially if the gallstones are the cause of her symptoms, it's crucial to first assess and manage any potential common bile duct stones. Directly proceeding to cholecystectomy without addressing potential common bile duct stones could lead to complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, given the patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings suggesting the presence of common bile duct stones, an MRCP is the most appropriate initial step to visualize the biliary system and confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A primigravida is in labour. Her per-vaginal examination revealed a posterior cervix with 5 cm cervical length, 1 cm dilatation, soft consistency, and head at -1 station. Calculate the modified Bishop score? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5

 

Explanation:

 

Bishop Score

 

  • This is a scoring system used to assess the favorability of the cervix to respond to induction of labor. 
  • A cervix that is soft in consistency, a little dilated, short in length, anteriorly placed and the station of the presenting low down will respond well to induction of labor. 
  • The Bishop score was replaced by the Modified Bishop score, wherein, the cervical effacement (in terms of percentage) was replaced by cervical length (in cm). 
  • The 5 components of the Modified Bishop score are:
    1. Cervical Dilatation
    2. Cervical length
    3. Cervical consistency
    4. Cervical Position
    5. Station of the presenting part

 

Easy to remember Mnemonic

 

B – Bishop

 

I – Effacement

 

S – Station of presenting part

 

H – Hard/ soft (consistency)

 

O – Os dilatation (cervical dilatation)

 

P – Position of the cervix

 

  • The scoring is as shown in the table.
  • Each component is scored from 0 to 3
  • The highest score is 13 and the lowest is 0
  • A favourable score is > 6. This means the patient will respond favorably to methods of induction of labor. 

 

 

Educational Objective:


The Modified Bishop score is used to assess the cervix's favorability for induction, and a score of 5 in this context would be based on specific factors.

 

Ref: Page no 600, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Blighted ovum
﻿﻿﻿Missed abortion
﻿﻿﻿Ectopic pregnancy

questions.text: A primigravida in her 10th week of gestation presents with spotting. On examination, the uterus corresponds to 12 weeks. Transvaginal ultrasound was done and it is given below. What is your diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hydatidiform mole

 

Explanation:


The typical ‘Snowstorm appearance’ on ultrasound is indicative of a hydatidiform mole. This appearance is characteristic of a complete molar pregnancy, where there is a proliferation of abnormal tissue instead of a viable embryo.

 

  • Complete Mole:
    • Ultrasound Finding: Snowstorm appearance with diffuse, heterogeneous echogenicity.
    • Genetics: Diploid with only paternal genetic material. It can occur due to either:
      • One sperm fertilizing an empty or inactivated ovum (androgenesis), leading to 46XX or 46XY.
      • Two sperm fertilizing an empty ovum (dispermy), also leading to 46XX or 46XY.
    • Clinical Management: Suction evacuation is the standard treatment.
  • Partial Mole:
    • Genetics: Triploid, with 69XXX or 69XXY, resulting from two sperm fertilizing one ovum.
    • Clinical Appearance: Typically has a more complex presentation with an abnormal fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blighted ovum: Also known as an anembryonic pregnancy, this occurs when a gestational sac forms but no embryo is visible. It does not present with the Snowstorm appearance and usually lacks the pronounced proliferation of tissue seen in a hydatidiform mole.

 

Option B. Missed abortion: This involves the retention of an embryo or fetus with no detectable heartbeat or growth. The ultrasound findings typically show a non-viable fetus without the characteristic snowstorm pattern of a hydatidiform mole.

 

Option C. Ectopic pregnancy: This occurs when a fertilized egg implants outside the uterus, often in the fallopian tubes. It would not present with the Snowstorm appearance but rather show a gestational sac or products of conception in an abnormal location.

 

Educational Objective:


The 'Snowstorm appearance' on transvaginal ultrasound is characteristic of a hydatidiform mole.

 

Ref: Page no 225, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Oxidase and catalase negative, does not ferment inulin
Ferments glucose and maltose but not inulin
Oxidase and catalase positive and does not ferment maltose or glucose

questions.text: A patient presented with meningitis, and the CSF sample was subjected to gram staining and microscopy and appears as shown in the microscopic image given below. Which of the following features/tests will be characteristic of the organism? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Catalase negative, optochin sensitive

 

This image is a light micrograph of Gram-stained S. pneumoniae (also known as S. pneumococcus), rounded bacteria (cocci) that usually occur in pairs and sometimes short chains. Their blue color indicates they are Gram-positive.

 

Meningitis occurs when bacteria enter the bloodstream and then cross the blood-brain barrier or through direct contact of meninges with the skin or nasal cavity. The most frequent focus of the infection is the nasopharynx colonized by S. pneumoniae that evades the host immune system. During IPD, the bloodstream becomes invaded, and complement and coagulation systems are activated. Inflammatory mediators are released massively, which makes it easier for the bacteria to cross the blood-brain barrier. Inflammation is responsible for all the typical findings of bacterial meningitis, i.e., CSF pleocytosis.

 

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Oxidase and catalase negative, does not ferment inulin: This description is not characteristic of Streptococcus pneumoniae. Oxidase-negative and catalase-negative bacteria include many streptococci, but inulin fermentation is not a typical test used for identifying S. pneumoniae.

 

Option B. Ferments glucose and maltose but not inulin: This characteristic fits some Neisseria species but not S. pneumoniae. S. pneumoniae ferments glucose and sometimes other carbohydrates but is best identified by its optochin sensitivity and bile solubility.

 

Option C. Oxidase and catalase positive and does not ferment maltose or glucose: This describes certain gram-negative bacteria, such as Neisseria species, which do not fit the description of S. pneumoniae.

 

Educational Objective

 

Streptococcus pneumoniae, a common cause of bacterial meningitis, is characterized by being catalase-negative, optochin-sensitive, and gram-positive lancet-shaped diplococci. These features help in its identification and differentiation from other bacterial pathogens.

questions.text: Fibers from the structure marked in blue, terminate at which of the following? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Red nucleus

 

The superior cerebellar peduncle is the peduncle that is highlighted in the picture. Deep cerebellar nuclei that extend to the brainstem, red nucleus, and thalamus are connected by fibres to the superior cerebellar peduncle. The fibres of the ventral spinocerebellar tract are also present.

 

 

 

All of the efferent fibres from the dentate, emboliform, and globose nuclei Majority of efferents from the fastigial nucleus pass via inferior cerebellar peduncle though few may pass via superior peduncle. The caudal mesencephalon is where its fibres decussate, and they are intended to synapse in the thalamus and opposite red nucleus. Only afferent fibres from the contralateral pontine nuclei are present in the middle cerebellar peduncle. Afferent and efferent fibres that travel to the vestibular nuclei are both present in the inferior cerebellar peduncle.

 

The image below summarizes the various tracts in the cerebellar unit.

 

 

  • It has two surfaces - superior and inferior separated by a horizontal fissure. It is connected to the other parts of the central nervous system via three peduncles
    • Superior cerebellar peduncle -connecting to the midbrain
    • Middle cerebellar peduncle - connecting to the pons
    • Inferior cerebellar peduncle - connecting to the medulla oblongata

 

The superior cerebellar peduncle, also known as the brachium conjunctivum, is a major white matter tract connecting the cerebellum to the midbrain. Its fibers originate in the cerebellum, ascend, and decussate (cross over) at the level of the midbrain to end primarily in the contralateral red nucleus and the thalamus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fastigial nucleus: The fastigial nucleus is one of the four deep cerebellar nuclei (others being the globose, emboliform, and dentate nuclei). While the fastigial nucleus does send fibers out of the cerebellum, it primarily connects through the inferior cerebellar peduncle to the vestibular nuclei and the reticular formation, not the superior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Option B. Inferior olivary nucleus: The inferior olivary nucleus is located in the medulla oblongata and is involved in motor learning and coordination. It primarily sends fibers to the cerebellum through the inferior cerebellar peduncle, and it receives cerebellar feedback, but not directly from the superior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Option D. Subthalamus: The subthalamus is part of the diencephalon and is closely related to the basal ganglia circuitry, particularly in the indirect pathway. While the subthalamus does receive some cerebellar input, the primary connection from the superior cerebellar peduncle is to the red nucleus and not directly to the subthalamus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The red nucleus is located in the midbrain and plays a role in motor coordination. Fibers from the cerebellum via the superior cerebellar peduncle decussate and terminate primarily in the contralateral red nucleus. From the red nucleus, some of these fibers continue on to the thalamus. Thus, the red nucleus is a major target of the superior cerebellar peduncle fibers.

questions.text: Identify the site of the lesion: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left occipital lobe

 

  • The visual field defect is right homonymous hemianopia with macular-sparing.
  • It is caused by lesions of the left occipital lobe, which is contralateral/crossing of fibers.
  • Head injury is a common cause of such lesions.
  • These lesions may be associated with visual hallucinations, denial of blindness (Anton syndrome), and the Riddoch phenomenon.
  • These lesions are commonly due to occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery. The part of the occipital lobe representing the peripheral field vision is supplied by the posterior cerebral artery.
  • The lesions generally spare the central vision/macular vision since the area at the tip of the calcarine cortex, representing the central macular vision, is supplied by a branch of the middle cerebral artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right Occipital Lobe: This would cause a left-sided homonymous hemianopia.

 

Option C. Left Geniculate Body: Lesions here typically produce similar visual field defects as occipital lobe lesions but may have different associated clinical signs and symptoms.

 

Option D. Optic Chiasma: Lesions at the optic chiasm typically produce bitemporal hemianopia, which is not demonstrated in the visual field tests provided.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lesion in the left occipital lobe is the most likely cause of the right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing shown in the visual field tests. This understanding is critical for accurately diagnosing the underlying condition, potentially a vascular event, and directing appropriate management and intervention strategies.

choices.text: Neurodegeneration with Brain Iron Accumulation

questions.text: Which of the following does not show both hyperkinetic and hypokinetic movements? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Huntington's chorea

 

Huntington's chorea is characterized by hyperkinetic movements such as chorea but does not typically present with hypokinetic movements.

 

Huntington's chorea presents with a classic triad of abnormal movements (chorea), dementia, and psychiatric manifestations. It also has a strong family history due to its inherited nature.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Parkinson's disease:  Parkinson's disease shows both tremors (hyperkinetic) and bradykinesia (hypokinetic).

 

Option B. Wilson's disease:  Wilson's disease can present with a combination of movement disorders.

 

Option C. Neurodegeneration with Brain Iron Accumulation:  Neurodegeneration with Brain Iron Accumulation also shows mixed movement disorders.

 

Educational Objective:


Huntington's chorea primarily presents with hyperkinetic movements and not hypokinetic movements.

choices.text: Ingestion of contaminated food and water

questions.text: A 45-year-old male worker presents to the emergency room with abdominal pain, irritability, fatigue, and memory problems. He works in a battery manufacturing factory for the last 20 years. On further investigations, he is diagnosed with lead poisoning. Which of the following is the most frequent mode of inorganic lead absorption contributing to his condition in such industrial environments? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inhaled lead dust

 

  • In industrial environments such as battery manufacturing factories, the most frequent mode of inorganic lead absorption is through inhalation of lead dust.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lead Poisoning is known as ‘Plumbism’, Saturnism or Painter’s Colic

 

  • Greatest source of lead in Lead Poisoning (Plumbism, Saturnism or Painter’s Colic) is Gasoline/petrol/vehicular exhaust/automobile exhaust
  • Mode of absorption: Lead can be absorbed by inhalation (most common mode), ingestion or through skin

 

Additional Information

 

Clinical picture of lead poisoning:

 

  • Facial pallor: Earliest and most consistent sign
  • Anemia: Microcytic hypochromic
  • Punctate basophilia or basophilic stippling of RBCs
  • Burtonian Line: Lead sulphide line on gums (upper jaw)
  • Lead colic: Constipation (but sometimes diarrhea)
  • Lead Palsy (Peripheral neuropathy): Wrist drop or Foot drop
  • Lead encephalopathy
  • CNS effects: mostly due to organic lead compounds

 

Diagnosis of lead poisoning:

 

 

A useful screening test is Coproporphyrin in Urine (CPU).

 

Treatment: EDTA

questions.text: Pacinian corpuscle is stimulated by which of the following? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pressure

 

Pacinian corpuscle is stimulated by pressure.

 

  • Pacinian corpuscles (Vater-Pacini or lamellar corpuscles) are the largest cutaneous mechanoreceptors for vibration and deep pressure and are essential for proprioception.
  • They can be found throughout the whole body; however, it is the hands and feet where they occur most numerously and tightly grouped.
  • They are composed of a nerve ending which is encapsulated by concentric layers of connective tissue that give it an onion-like appearance and are present in the dermis. The sensory nerves from cutaneous mechanoreceptors are myelinated Aα and Aβ fibers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pain: Incorrect. Pain is detected by nociceptors, not Pacinian corpuscles.

 

Option B. Temperature: Incorrect. Temperature is detected by thermoreceptors, not Pacinian corpuscles.

 

Option C. Touch: Incorrect. Touch is detected by various mechanoreceptors, including Meissner's corpuscles and Merkel discs, but Pacinian corpuscles specifically detect deep pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pacinian corpuscles are specialized mechanoreceptors that detect deep pressure and vibration, playing a crucial role in proprioception and providing sensory feedback about the physical environment.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements accurately describe the operation and management of Mobile Medical Units (MMUs)? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. MMUs are run by the government
  2. MMUs are run by external agencies with medical supplies given by the government.
  3. MMUs are run by the government and medical supplies are also given by the government.
  4. MMUs are run by external agencies and medical supplies are also given by the external agency.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, and 3

 

  • MMUs can be operated by either the Government or an external agency; however, the availability of drugs and medical supplies is exclusively the responsibility of the Government.
  • Mobile Medical Units (MMU) represents a significant project within NRHM, aimed at delivering a variety of healthcare services to individuals residing in distant, hard-to-reach, unserved, and underserved regions, encompassing both rural and urban locations.
  • The goal is to bring essential healthcare services directly to the residents in these areas.

 

There are 3 models of operationalizing MMUs:

 

  1. Government operated MMU
  2. MMU operation is outsourced to an external agency, while the government covers capital expenses, medication, and supplies.
  3. External agency outsourcing includes both capital and operational expenses for MMUs.

 

The government is responsible for providing medication and supplies. MMUs offer essential primary healthcare services for prevalent illnesses (both communicable and non-communicable), reproductive and child health (RCH) services, screening examinations, and necessary referrals to advanced facilities and specialists. Medical Officer-led clinical services are delivered by a team, while mobilization and outreach activities are undertaken by ANMs and ASHA personnel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Services and Resources of MMUs:

 

  • MMUs offer a variety of services, including primary care for common diseases, reproductive and child health services, diagnostic screenings, and referrals to specialized care.
  • They are equipped with facilities for basic diagnostic tests such as blood glucose monitoring, pregnancy testing, and sputum sample collection, among others.
  • Human resources typically include a medical officer, a nurse, a lab technician, a pharmacist/administrative assistant, and a driver/support staff.

questions.text: Cytochrome C oxidase is inhibited by all EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methane

 

  • Methane does not inhibit cytochrome C oxidase.
  • Cytochrome C oxidase is primarily inhibited by substances that interfere with the electron transport chain, such as cyanide and carbon monoxide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. H2S (Hydrogen Sulfide):

  • H2S can inhibit cytochrome C oxidase.
  • It is a known inhibitor of this enzyme and can disrupt mitochondrial respiration.

 

Option C. CO (Carbon Monoxide):

  • CO is a potent inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase.
  • It binds to the same heme groups in the enzyme's active site as oxygen, preventing oxygen from binding and disrupting electron transport.

 

Option D. Cyanide:

  • Cyanide is a strong inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase.
  • It binds to the iron in the enzyme's heme groups, blocking the transfer of electrons in the electron transport chain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CN, CO and H2S are inhibitors of Cytochrome c Oxidase (Complex IV of ETC). They inhibit by non-competitive inhibition and this type of inhibition is mostly irreversible. For a complete list of ETC inhibitors refer to table below:

 

Inhibitor of ETC complexes

 

 

Ref - Harper 31st e/p 123

choices.text: Valvular heart disease due to rheumatic heart disease
Sudden cardiac death due to arrhythmia
Sudden cardiac death due to atherosclerosis

questions.text: An unfortunate incident occurred during a football match, where a young 20-year-old athlete tragically collapsed and was subsequently rushed to the hospital. Despite all efforts, the medical team could not save him, and he was pronounced deceased. The autopsy image provided gives us important information to investigate the cause of his untimely passing. What can be the most likely cause of death? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sudden cardiac death due to arrhythmia

 

Given clinical scenario, image showing asymmetric septal hypertrophy and histo image shows extensive myocyte disarray suggests a diagnosis of Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and cause of sudden death in this scenario is Arrhythmia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Valvular heart disease due to rheumatic heart disease: Valvular heart disease due to Rheumatic Heart Disease typically presents with valvular dysfunction (e.g., mitral stenosis) and is less common in causing sudden death in young athletes.

 

Option C. Death due to hypertrophied ventricle: While hypertrophied ventricles are a feature of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, the immediate cause of death is usually due to an arrhythmia, not merely the hypertrophy itself.

 

Option D. Sudden cardiac death due to atherosclerosis: Sudden cardiac death due to atherosclerosis is more common in older adults and less likely in a 20-year-old athlete.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sudden cardiac death due to arrhythmia is the most likely cause of death in young athlete with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, as indicated by the clinical scenario and autopsy findings.

 

HOCM is characterised by histological findings of myocyte disarray. (recent INICET ques)

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1061

questions.text: Which of the following can be used in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B6

 

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) is used in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia.

 

The sideroblastic anemia comprise a group of disorders of diverse etiology in which the nucleated erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, show characteristic ‘ringed sideroblasts.’

 

SIDEROCYTES are red cells containing granules of non-haem iron. These granules stain ositively with Prussian blue reaction as well as stain with Romanowsky dyes where they are referred to as Pappenheimer bodies.

 

SIDEROBLASTS are nucleated red cells (normoblasts) containing siderotic granules which stain positively with Prussian blue reaction. Depending upon the number, size and distribution of siderotic granules, sideroblasts may be normal or abnormal.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B12: Important for DNA synthesis and prevention of megaloblastic anemia but not directly involved in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia.

 

Option C. Vitamin B1: Known as thiamine, involved in carbohydrate metabolism, but does not play a role in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia.

 

Option D. Iron: Iron supplementation would not help and could worsen sideroblastic anemia, as the issue lies in the utilization of iron, not in its deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) is used in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia as it is a cofactor in the heme synthesis pathway and can correct the underlying metabolic defect in certain cases.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to OPD with proptosis of left eye. On investigation, it was found to be a Desmin positive tumour. What can be the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma

 

Given clinical scenario and tumor showing Desmin positive, points to a diagnosis of Embryonal Rhabdomyosarcoma.

 

Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma presents as a soft gray infiltrative mass. The tumor cells mimic skeletal muscle at various stages of differentiation and consist of sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells. Rhabdomyoblasts with straplike cytoplasm and visible cross-striations may be present.

 

Sarcoma botryoides is a variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma that develops in the walls of hollow viscera such as the urinary bladder and vagina.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ewing's sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is typically positive for CD99 and is more commonly found in bone or soft tissue, not usually associated with Desmin positivity.

 

Option C. Leukemia: Leukemia cells are positive for CD45 (leukocyte common antigen) and are not associated with Desmin positivity or presenting as a soft tissue mass with proptosis.

 

Option D. Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina, typically presenting with leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) and is associated with RB1 gene mutations. It is not associated with Desmin positivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, a common pediatric soft tissue sarcoma, is typically Desmin-positive and can present with proptosis, particularly when it arises in the orbit.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 2435-2437

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents with complaints of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. Drug of choice to treat this condition is? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metronidazole

 

Explanation:


The patient presents with foul-smelling vaginal discharge, which is a common symptom of bacterial vaginosis (BV). In bacterial vaginosis, the correct treatment is Metronidazole.

 

  • Bacterial vaginosis is often caused by an imbalance in the normal bacterial flora of the vagina, commonly involving Gardnerella vaginalis. The condition is diagnosed using Amsel's Criteria, which include:
    1. Thin, white homogenous vaginal discharge: The discharge is typically thin and white, and may have a fishy odor.
    2. pH of Vaginal fluid > 4.5: This elevated pH level is higher than the normal acidic environment of the vagina.
    3. Fishy odor of discharge on adding 10% KOH (Whiff test): The discharge develops a characteristic fishy odor when mixed with potassium hydroxide.
    4. Presence of Clue cells on microscopy: Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells that have a stippled appearance due to adherence of bacteria.

 

Metronidazole is the first-line treatment for bacterial vaginosis, and it is typically administered as oral tablets (500 mg twice daily for 7 days).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Clindamycin: While Clindamycin can be used to treat bacterial vaginosis, it is generally not the first choice. Metronidazole is preferred due to its effectiveness and established use.

 

Option C. Cotrimoxazole: This antibiotic is used for a variety of bacterial infections but is not effective for bacterial vaginosis.

 

Option D. Azithromycin: This is a macrolide antibiotic used primarily for sexually transmitted infections such as chlamydia and is not used for bacterial vaginosis.

 

Educational Objective:


The drug of choice for treating bacterial vaginosis is Metronidazole.

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented with hearing loss and tinnitus. A histology image is shown below. What can be the diagnosis for this patient?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Schwannoma

 

The given clinical scenario and histology image showing Verocay bodies are suggestive of Schwannoma /Acoustic neuroma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurofibroma is a benign tumor that develops along nerve cells. Histology image shows wreath like multinucleated giant cells.

 

 

Option B. Leiomyoma on histology shows well-differentiated, regular, spindle-shaped smooth muscle cells with hyalinization.

 

 

Option D. Rhabdomyoma on microscopy shows enlarged myocytes with abundant glycogen. Post-processing, glycogen content gets reduced and look like thin strands.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schwannoma is a benign tumor often associated with unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus, diagnosed via characteristic histological patterns and confirmed with MRI. It requires careful management, sometimes involving advanced surgical techniques such as Gamma Knife surgery.

questions.text: A 35-year-old car racer is brought to the emergency department after a car accident on the race track. He is unconscious and is immediately put on mechanical ventilation. He opens his eyes on verbal command and moves all four limbs spontaneously. Calculate his GCS: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6

 

His GCS is Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6.

 

Eye-opening to verbal command - 3

 

Movement of all 4 limbs spontaneously - 6

 

In the case of endotracheal intubation, the verbal response score is noted as NT.

 

Total GCS score is not recorded since one of the components is non-testable (NT).

questions.text:
Which of the following are the objective tests for the hearing? (INICET May 2021)

 

  1. BERA (Brainstem evoked response audiometry)
  2. OAE (Otoacoustic emission)
  3. PTA (Pure tone audiometry)
  4. Tympanometry
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

 

Objective tests for hearing do not require the active cooperation or response from the patient and are thus particularly useful in non-cooperative subjects such as young children or those who might simulate hearing loss.

 

1. BERA - Also called BAER or BAEP (brainstem auditory evoked response or potential) is an objective test to elicit brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts. It is a noninvasive technique to find the integrity of central auditory pathways through the VIIIth nerve, pons and midbrain

 

2. OAE is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by outer hair cells of a normal cochlea and can be elicited by a very sensitive microphone placed in the external ear canal and analyzed by a computer.

 

4. Tympanometry is an objective test for compliance or stiffness of the tympano-ossicular system. It evaluates the mobility of the eardrum (tympanic membrane) and the conduction bones of the middle ear, providing useful information about middle ear pressure and fluid presence.

 

Other Option:

 

3. PTA (pure tone audiometry): This is a subjective test as it relies on the patient's response to pure tone stimuli. It is not included as an objective test because it requires the patient's active participation to indicate when a sound is heard. Subjective tests such as PTA, tuning fork tests, and speech audiometry depend on patient interaction and are susceptible to voluntary or involuntary response errors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Objective hearing tests like BERA, OAE, and Tympanometry provide essential diagnostic information without the need for patient interaction, distinguishing them from subjective tests like Pure Tone Audiometry which rely on patient responses.

questions.text: During your clinical rotation, you notice the different color-coded waste bins meticulously arranged by the nursing staff as per the hospital's waste management protocol. If you were to guide a new intern about the appropriate disposal of items, which item among the following would you instruct them to discard in the black bin? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glove paper cover

 

  • The paper cover for gloves constitutes regular solid waste, which should be placed in the designated black bin.
  • All types of non-infectious general refuse, including food waste, paper waste, and mineral water bottles, ought to be deposited in the black bins.
  • Bedsheets and linens that are soiled and contaminated with blood or bodily fluids should be appropriately disposed of in the yellow bin.
  • Plastic materials that are recyclable, such as gloves and contaminated gloves, should be placed in the red bins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Soiled linen bedsheet: Should be disposed of in the yellow bin for contaminated waste.

 

Option C. Gloves: Should be placed in the red bin for recyclable materials.

 

Option D. Contaminated gloves: Also go in the red bin for medical waste.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-infectious general refuse, such as glove paper covers, should be discarded in the black bin.

choices.text: Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release
Cleavage of SNARE proteins, preventing Ach release

questions.text: A 45-year-old man developed generalized muscle spasm with arching of his back as shown in the image, a few days after sustaining a puncture wound to his leg. The toxin responsible for this type of abnormal posturing acts by which of the following mechanisms? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release

 

This abnormal posturing is caused by tetanospasmin which is produced by clostridium tetani. It inhibits presynaptic GABA and glycine release.

 

 

Clostridium tetani is an obligate anaerobic, gram-positive bacillus with terminal round spore (drumstick appearance).

 

Tetanus is manifested by skeletal muscle spasms and autonomic nervous system disturbance. Tetanus only affects skeletal muscle, smooth muscle, and cardiac muscle function normally.

 

C. tetani produces two exotoxins–tetanolysin and tetanospasmin.

 

  1. Tetanolysin is a heat-labile, oxygen-labile hemolysin antigenically related to the oxygen-labile hemolysins produced by C. perfringens, S. pyogenes, and S. pneumoniae. Tetanolysin damages otherwise viable tissue surrounding the infection and optimizes the conditions for bacterial multiplication.
  2. Tetanospasmin (or tetanus toxin) is a heat-labile, oxygen-stable, plasmid-coded neurotoxin responsible for disease manifestations. Tetanus neurotoxin is released upon cell lysis after bacterial growth under anaerobic conditions (e.g., in deep puncture wounds). It is antigenic and is specifically neutralized by its antitoxin. Its toxoid form is used for vaccine preparation.

 

Mechanism of Tetanus Toxin-

 

Tetanus toxin binds to polysialogangliosides receptors present on motor nerve terminals which results in toxin internalization.

 

Following internalization, tetanus toxin gets transported in a retrograde way from the peripheral nervous system to the central nervous system by retrograde axonal transport. When tetanus toxin reaches inhibitory neuron terminals, it prevents the presynaptic release of inhibitory neurotransmitters glycine and gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA).

 

Incubation period of tetanus is about 6-10 days.

 

 

Clinical features - Patients have prolonged muscle spasms of both flexor and extensor muscles. Patients with tetanus have spastic muscle contractions, difficulty opening the jaw (called lockjaw, “trismus”), a characteristic smile called “risus sardonicus” and contractions of back muscles resulting in backward arching (Opisthotonos position). Patients are extremely irritable, and tetanic seizures develop, brought about by violent, painful muscle contractions following some minor stimulus, such as noise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Presynaptic inhibition of Ach receptors: This mechanism is not involved in the action of tetanospasmin. It is more relevant to the action of botulinum toxin.

 

Option C. Postsynaptic inhibition of GABA: This is not the mechanism of action for tetanospasmin. Tetanospasmin acts presynaptically.

 

Option D. Cleavage of SNARE proteins, preventing Ach release: This describes the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin, not tetanospasmin. Botulinum toxin cleaves SNARE proteins, which prevents the release of acetylcholine (Ach) at the neuromuscular junction, leading to flaccid paralysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetanospasmin, the toxin responsible for tetanus, acts by inhibiting the presynaptic release of the inhibitory neurotransmitters GABA and glycine, leading to unopposed muscle contraction and the characteristic symptoms of tetanus, such as muscle spasms and opisthotonos.

questions.text:
An orthopedic surgeon plans to treat a Colle’s fracture. What are the steps involved in applying a cast for the same?(INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Palmar flexion
  2. Traction
  3. Ulnar deviation
  4. Application of plaster of Paris
questions.solution:
Ans. C) II, I, III, IV

 

COLLE’S FRACTURE

 

  • Colles fracture is fracture of lower end of radius at its corticocancellous junction.
  • It mostly occur in post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly women.
  • Symptoms and Signs:
    • Fracture of the distal radius, commonly referred to as a Colle’s fracture, is typically the result of a FOOSH injury (Fall on outstretched hand) with wrist in extension.
    • Patients present with swelling, ecchymosis, tenderness, and painful range of motion of the distal forearm.
    • On examination, the classic “dinner fork” deformity (dorsal displacement of the distal fragment and volar angulation of the distal intact radius with radial shortening) may be identified.

 

 

 

  • Complications:
    • Early complications may include median nerve neuropathy, extensor pollicis longus tendon rupture, and compartment syndrome.
    • Late complications may include radiocarpal arthrosis, complex regional pain syndrome, cosmetic changes of the wrist, and fracture malunion or nonunion.
    • Finger stiffness is most common complication.
    • Malunion is the 2nd most common complication and it leads to dinner fork deformity.
