questions.text: Which of the following components of the fungal cell wall is not seen in mucormycosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beta 1, 3, glucan

 

An abundant cell wall polysaccharide, (1-3)-β-d-glucan (BDG) is found in most fungi, with the notable exception of the cryptococci, the zygomycetes (mucor and Rhizopus), and Blastomyces dermatitidis, which either lack the glucan entirely or produce it at minimal levels.

 

Fungal cell wall:

 

  • Fungal cell walls are rigid and contain complex polysaccharides called chitin (adds structural strength) and glucans.
  • Ergosterol is the steroid molecule in the cell membranes that replaces the cholesterol found in animal cell membranes.

 

Clinical significance of Beta-1, 3-d-glucan:

 

G-test: Detects a-3 glucan. Used in diagnosis of candidiasis.

 

Tests for beta-d-glucan: Raised levels are seen in candidiasis, aspergillosis, and pneumonia due to Pneumocystis carnii.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mannoproteins: Mannoproteins are glycoproteins found in the fungal cell wall, contributing to its structure and function.

 

Option C. Chitin: Chitin is a structural polysaccharide found in the cell walls of fungi, including those causing mucormycosis. It provides rigidity and strength to the cell wall.

 

Option D. Ergosterol: Ergosterol is a component of fungal cell membranes, not the cell wall. It replaces cholesterol found in animal cell membranes and is essential for maintaining membrane integrity and function in fungi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta 1, 3, glucan is absent or minimally present in the cell walls of fungi causing mucormycosis, distinguishing them from many other fungi that have this polysaccharide as a major cell wall component. This characteristic is significant in the diagnosis and treatment of fungal infections.

questions.text: A stool sample is collected. The specimen is processed for examination and is labeled at different levels as A, B, C, and D. Identify the level at which parasitic ova will be seen when viewed under a microscope? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

The above image shows formal ether sedimentation technique.

 

Sedimentation techniques use solutions of lower specific gravity than the parasitic organisms, thus concentrating the latter in the sediment. It takes advantage of the high specific gravity of protozoan cysts and helminth eggs compared to water. Their natural tendency to settle out in aqueous solutions can be accelerated by light centrifugation.

 

Formalin fixes the eggs, larvae, oocysts, and spores, so that they are no longer infectious, as well as preserves their morphology. Fecal debris is extracted into the ethyl acetate phase of the solution. Parasitic elements are sedimented at the bottom.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. A: This level contains ether, which is used to extract fecal debris and is found at the top of the tube after centrifugation.

 

Option B. B: This level contains the plug of debris, which is a layer of waste material that is separated from the parasitic elements and sits below the ether layer.

 

Option C. C: This level contains formalin, which fixes and preserves the morphology of the parasitic elements. The formalin layer sits above the sediment but below the plug of debris.

 

Educational Objective

 

In the formal ether sedimentation technique, parasitic ova, cysts, and larvae will be concentrated in the sediment at the bottom of the tube, labeled as level D. This sediment is where parasitic elements are found and examined under a microscope.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image. (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenoid facies

 

The above given image shows adenoid facies. The characteristic features are visible which are: -

 

  • Elongated face with dull expression
  • Open mouth
  • Hitched up upper lip
  • Prominent upper teeth, which appear crowded
  • High arched hard palate
  • Pinched-in nose

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Goldenhar syndrome: Typically presents with abnormalities of the eye, ear, and spine, none of which are visible in this image.

 

Option C. Horse facies: Characterized by an elongated face with prominent jaw structures, which does not match the features in the image.

 

Option D. Frog facies: Often includes a wide mouth and bulging eyes, which are not present in this child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoid facies can be recognized by characteristic features such as elongated face, open mouth posture due to nasal obstruction, hitched up upper lip revealing crowded upper teeth, and a pinched-in nose. It's associated with chronic adenoid hypertrophy, impacting the facial structure and respiratory function.

questions.text: At which level does the nerve supply for the marked structure arise? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Red nucleus

 

Explanation:

 

The medial rectus muscle is the one highlighted in the provided CT picture. The oculomotor nerve, whose nucleus is located at the level of the superior colliculus adjacent to the red nucleus, supplies the medial rectus.

 

The nuclear complex from which the oculomotor nerve arises consists of:

 

  • Several groups of large motor neurons are collectively called the oculomotor nucleus. The motor neuron groups of the oculomotor nucleus innervate, in dorsoventral order, the ipsilateral inferior rectus, inferior oblique, and medial rectus. A medially placed column of cells innervates the contralateral superior rectus.
  • Smaller preganglionic parasympathetic neurons called the Edinger-Westphal preganglionic nucleus

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subthalamic nuclei: The subthalamic nucleus is part of the diencephalon and is closely associated with the basal ganglia circuitry. It plays a role in motor control. It's not directly associated with the oculomotor nerve's origin.

 

Option C. Decussation of pyramidal tract: The decussation of the pyramidal tract (motor fibers) occurs in the lower medulla oblongata, well below the level of the oculomotor nerve's origin. This is where the majority of motor fibers from one hemisphere cross to the opposite side.

 

Option D. Olivary nucleus: The olivary nucleus is located in the medulla oblongata and is primarily associated with the coordination of motor tasks. Again, it's located caudally relative to the oculomotor nerve's origin in the midbrain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The oculomotor nerve (CN III) arises from the anterior aspect of the midbrain, at the level of the superior colliculus. Its nucleus is situated ventral to the cerebral aqueduct and in close proximity to the red nucleus. Hence, the oculomotor nerve is often associated with the level of the red nucleus in the midbrain. It exits the midbrain medial to the cerebral peduncle.

choices.text: Only 1 is correct.
1 & 2 are correct.
2 & 3 are correct.
1, 2 & 4 are correct.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements accurately describe the effects of Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency? (AIIMS MAY 2021)

 

  1. Decrease in reduced glutathione
  2. Decreased NADPH
  3. Decreased lipid peroxidation
  4. Decreased RBC membrane damage
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 & 2 are correct.

 

 

 

1. Decrease in reduced glutathione:


This statement is correct. G6PD deficiency leads to reduced levels of NADPH, which is necessary to maintain GSH in its reduced form. Without sufficient GSH, RBCs are more susceptible to oxidative damage, which can lead to hemolysis.

 

2. Decreased NADPH:


This statement is also correct. G6PD deficiency directly results in decreased production of NADPH in the pentose phosphate pathway. NADPH is necessary for the regeneration of reduced glutathione, which protects cells from oxidative stress.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Decreased lipid peroxidation:


This statement is incorrect. In fact, G6PD deficiency leads to increased oxidative stress, which can result in increased lipid peroxidation, not a decrease. Lipid peroxidation damages cell membranes, contributing to RBC hemolysis.

 

4. Decreased RBC membrane damage:


This statement is incorrect. The decreased levels of reduced glutathione and increased oxidative stress lead to more, not less, RBC membrane damage. This damage makes the RBCs more prone to hemolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

G6PD deficiency leads to decreased levels of NADPH and reduced glutathione, which are essential for protecting RBCs from oxidative damage.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1197

questions.text: According to IADPSG, what is the cut-off value of fasting blood glucose for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) > 92 mg/dL

 

Explanation:

 

The International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Groups (IADPSG) has established criteria for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). According to their guidelines:

 

  • The fasting blood glucose cut-off value for diagnosing GDM during a 75g oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) is >92 mg/dL.

 

This value is used as part of a comprehensive assessment, including 1-hour and 2-hour postprandial glucose levels. The IADPSG criteria for GDM diagnosis include:

 

  • Fasting: ≥92 mg/dL
  • 1-hour: ≥180 mg/dL
  • 2-hour: ≥153 mg/dL

 

If any one of these values is abnormal, the diagnosis of GDM can be made.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. >95 mg/dL: This is not the IADPSG recommended cut-off for fasting blood glucose. It is higher than the specified cut-off value for diagnosing GDM.

 

Option C. >106 mg/dL: This value is significantly higher than the recommended cut-off. It exceeds the threshold for diagnosing GDM according to IADPSG guidelines.

 

Option D. >90 mg/dL: While this value is close, it is slightly below the IADPSG recommended cut-off of >92 mg/dL for diagnosing GDM.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cut-off value of fasting blood glucose for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus according to IADPSG is >92 mg/dL.

 

Ref: Page no 326, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: CT angiography to look for large vessel occlusion

questions.text: A 50-year-old man suddenly developed right-sided weakness and aphasia within 2 hours. His BP recorded was 160/110 mmHg and NCCT was clear. What is the next step in management? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thrombolysis

 

With a BP below 185/110 mmHg, clear NCCT, and symptoms within 4.5 hours, the patient qualifies for thrombolysis, the standard treatment for acute ischemic stroke to dissolve clots and restore blood flow.

 

If the blood pressure (BP) is more than or equal to 185/110 mmHg, administer IV labetalol to lower the BP to less than 185/110 mmHg before immediately proceeding with thrombolysis. CT angiography can be performed while thrombolysis is ongoing. Start the thrombolytic agent in the CT room and simultaneously inject a bolus of contrast for the CT angiogram to check for large vessel occlusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT angiography: CT angiography can be done simultaneously with thrombolysis but not instead of it.

 

Option B. MRI: MRI is not the immediate next step when NCCT is clear.

 

Option C. Labetalol: Labetalol is used to lower BP but not the primary treatment in this context.

 

Educational Objective:


In acute ischemic stroke with BP < 185/110 and clear NCCT, thrombolysis is the next step.

questions.text: RNAi acts through? (INICET May 2021
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Knock down

 

Explanation:

 

Gene knock down is when function of the gene present is suppressed by inhibiting or degrading the target mRNA so that it cannot form its protein. This is also known as post transcriptional gene silencing or RNA interference (RNAi). This is mediated by micro RNA (miRNA) or small interfering RNA (siRNA) which are small 20-27 nucleotides long non-coding RNAs. miRNA based RNAi involves the uses of three enzymes DROSHA, PASHA and DICER.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knock out: This involves removing or taking a gene out, resulting in a complete loss of gene function.

 

Option C. Knock in: This involves inserting a gene into a specific location within the genome.

 

Option D. Knock up: This term is not used in the context of gene manipulation.

 

Educational Objective:


RNA interference (RNAi) acts through gene knock down by suppressing the function of a gene via degradation or inhibition of its target mRNA, preventing protein formation.

 

Ref- Harper 31st e/p 346-348

questions.text: A servant was sexually assaulted by her boss. There was presence of white stains on the clothes of the victim. Barberio's test was performed on the stains. Which of the following is detected by this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Spermine

 

  • Barberio’s test detects the presence of spermine (prostatic component of semen).
  • In this test the alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to dried seminal stain which produces the yellow needle shaped crystals are of spermine picrate.

 

Barberio’s test

 

  • Reagent: Picric Acid
  • Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland)
  • Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Acid phosphatase: It is detected in acid phosphatase test

 

Option C) Choline: It is detected in Florence test

 

Option D) Fructose: Produced by Seminal vesicles, but not commonly detected

 

Educational Objective

 

Tests for seminal stains

 

1) Presumptive test for seminal stains:

 

  • Fluorescence under UV light
  • Microchemical tests: ﻿﻿Florence test and ﻿Barberio's test   

 

2) Confirmatory Tests for Semen

 

  • Detection of complete sperm under the microscope (Best test)﻿﻿
  • Acid phosphatase test (second best test): It is produced by prostate gland. Acid phosphatase enzyme in semen is much higher concentration than other body fluids
  • ﻿﻿Creatine phosphokinase test: It is a component of Spermatozoa.
  • Prostate specific antigen

choices.text: Cusco's speculum
﻿﻿﻿Sims' speculum

questions.text: Identify the instrument given below? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cusco's speculum

 

Explanation:

 

  • The instrument shown in the image is Cusco's speculum.
  • Cusco's speculum is a self-retaining bivalve speculum used for visualization of the cervix, vaginal fornices and for performing pap smear.
  • Advantage: Self retaining
  • Disadvantage: Less space so can’t be used for some procedures, obscures the vaginal walls so vaginal lesion may be missed

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sim Speculum:

 

 

Option C. Proctoscope

 

 

Option D. Doyen Retractor

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cusco's speculum is a self-retaining bivalve speculum used for visualizing the cervix and vaginal fornices.

 

Ref: Page no 628, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Insulin inhibits which of the following lipase enzymes? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hormone sensitive lipase

 

Insulin inhibits hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL). Hormone-sensitive lipase is responsible for the breakdown of triglycerides stored in adipose tissue into fatty acids and glycerol. When insulin levels are high, such as after a meal, it promotes fat storage and inhibits HSL activity, reducing the release of fatty acids from adipose tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lipoprotein lipase: Insulin activates lipoprotein lipase (LPL). Lipoprotein lipase is an enzyme that plays a crucial role in the metabolism of lipoproteins, specifically in the hydrolysis of triglycerides in circulating chylomicrons and very low-density lipoproteins (VLDL). Insulin promotes LPL activity, which facilitates the uptake of fatty acids into adipose tissue and muscle for storage and energy utilization.

 

Option C. Acid lipase: Insulin does not have a direct inhibitory effect on acid lipase. Acid lipase enzymes, such as gastric lipase and lysosomal lipase, function in different environments and processes compared to the regulation of lipids by insulin in the bloodstream.

 

Option D. Alkaline lipase: Insulin does not have a direct inhibitory effect on alkaline lipase. Alkaline lipases are typically found in the pancreas and function in the digestion of dietary fats. They are not directly regulated by insulin in the same way as the lipases involved in adipose tissue and circulating lipoprotein metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulin is an anabolic hormone so activates anabolic enzymes and inhibits catabolic enzymes. Hormone sensitive lipase is a catabolic enzyme present in adipose tissue cells which causes release of fatty acids from stored TG during starvation. So, it is activated by catabolic enzyme Glucagon. Lipoprotein lipase on the other hand is an anabolic enzyme and release FA from TG of VLDL and chylomicrons in fed state. Understanding the regulatory role of insulin in lipase enzymes is essential for medical students. Insulin inhibits hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) to promote fat storage and activates lipoprotein lipase (LPL) to facilitate fatty acid uptake, which helps maintain energy homeostasis and lipid metabolism in the body.

 

Ref- Harper 31st e/p 240, 245

questions.text: Which of the following is not a major diagnostic criterion of neuromyelitis Optica? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Focal epilepsy

 

Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) spectrum disorder, also known as Devic's disease, is an autoimmune condition characterized by severe, recurrent episodes of optic neuritis and myelitis. The diagnostic criteria for NMO spectrum disorders include specific clinical syndromes.  

 

Focal epilepsy is not a diagnostic criterion for NMO. While seizures can occur in NMOSD due to brain lesions, focal epilepsy itself is not a major diagnostic feature.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Area postrema syndrome  is major criteria. This is characterized by intractable nausea, vomiting, or hiccups, which is due to lesions in the area postrema of the brainstem.

 

Option B. Acute myelitis is major criteria. Inflammation of the spinal cord, usually longitudinally extensive (spanning three or more vertebral segments).

 

Option D. Optic neuritis is major criteria. This involves inflammation of the optic nerve, leading to vision loss or impairment, often affecting both eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnostic Criteria for Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (NMOSD)

 

Most Common Core Clinical criteria:

 

  1. Longitudinal extensive transverse myelitis (acute myelitis)
  2. Optic neuritis, often bilateral
  3. Area postrema syndrome

 

Less Common Clinical Criteria:

 

  1. Acute brainstem syndrome
  2. Acute diencephalic syndrome, which can manifest as symptomatic narcolepsy
  3. Symptomatic cerebral syndrome (symptomatic cerebral lesions)

 

Some patients with NMOSD may have anti-NMO IgG antibody positivity, also known as anti-aquaporin 4 antibody (AQP4-IgG).

choices.text: Mandatory episiotomy
Manual perineal support and warm compresses
Maintain head in deflexion and deliver
Deliver in lithotomy position only

questions.text: Which of the following is recommended by the WHO for the management of the second stage of labor? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Manual perineal support and warm compresses


The WHO guidelines for managing the second stage of labor emphasize techniques to reduce perineal trauma and enhance maternal comfort. The use of manual perineal support and warm compresses is recommended to protect the perineum during delivery and reduce the incidence of severe perineal tears.

 

  • Manual Perineal Support and Warm Compresses:
    • Manual Support: Hands-on guarding of the perineum during delivery helps control the speed of delivery and reduces the risk of severe perineal tears.
    • Warm Compresses: Applying warm compresses to the perineum can help relax the tissues and make them more pliable, further reducing the risk of tearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mandatory Episiotomy: Not Recommended: Routine episiotomy is no longer recommended by the WHO. It is only indicated in specific cases where it is necessary to expedite delivery for the safety of the mother or baby.

 

Option C. Maintain Head in Deflexion and Deliver: Not Recommended: The recommendation is to allow the fetal head to assume the most optimal position for delivery rather than intentionally maintaining deflexion, which may hinder the delivery process.

 

Option D. Deliver in Lithotomy Position Only: Not Recommended: The WHO supports a variety of birthing positions based on the mother’s preference and comfort. Restricting delivery to the lithotomy position is not recommended; instead, women should be encouraged to choose their preferred position.

 

Educational Objective:


Manual perineal support and warm compresses are recommended by the WHO to reduce perineal trauma during the second stage of labor.

 

Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/337693/9789240017566-eng.pdf

choices.text: Follow up 6 monthly for 2 years and then yearly follow up

questions.text: A 63-year-old female patient presented with a 5x1 cm lump in the left upper outer quadrant, with no axillary lymph node involvement. Mammography revealed BIRADS 4b staging. She underwent breast conservation surgery, and the final HE reports showed high nuclear grade DCIS with 7 mm margin clearance. What is the further management? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

After breast-conserving surgery (BCS) for ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), adjuvant radiotherapy is typically recommended. Radiotherapy has been shown to significantly reduce the risk of local recurrence after BCS for DCIS. In this patient, despite having a 7 mm margin clearance, the presence of high nuclear grade DCIS warrants the use of adjuvant radiotherapy to minimize the risk of local recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adjuvant chemotherapy: Chemotherapy is primarily used for invasive breast cancers, especially when there is a high risk of systemic spread. DCIS is a non-invasive form of breast cancer, and hence systemic chemotherapy is not typically indicated.

 

Option C. Follow up 6 monthly for 2 years and then yearly follow up: Regular follow-up is crucial for any patient who has undergone treatment for breast cancer, but it is not the primary management strategy immediately after surgery for high nuclear grade DCIS.

 

Option D. Trastuzumab therapy: Trastuzumab is a targeted therapy used for HER2-positive invasive breast cancers. DCIS that is HER2-positive does not typically receive trastuzumab therapy, as the benefits of such treatment in non-invasive cancer have not been clearly established.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Based on the Van Nuys prognostic index, the patient’s score is: High grade- 3 points, Margins 7 mm-2 points, Size 5 cm- 3 points and age 63 years- 1 point= 9 points.

 

The recommended next step in the patient's management would be adjuvant radiotherapy for scores 7 to 9.

 

 

Score: 4 to 6: wide excision alone

 

7 to 9: Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

10 to 12: Mastectomy

choices.text: Early discharge, skin to skin contact, prevent infection
Early discharge, skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding
Skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, prevent infection
Early discharge, exclusive breastfeeding and prevent infection

questions.text: Which of the following are components of kangaroo mother care? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Early discharge, skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding.

 

Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) is an essential practice for the care of low birthweight infants, particularly in resource-limited settings. The core components of KMC include:

 

  • Skin-to-skin contact: The baby is placed between the mother's breasts in an upright position. The baby's hips are abducted and flexed in a "frog position," and the arms are also flexed. This close contact helps regulate the baby's temperature, breathing, and heart rate.
  • Exclusive breastfeeding: KMC promotes exclusive breastfeeding, which is crucial for the baby's nutrition and immune protection.
  • Early discharge and ambulatory care: KMC supports the early discharge of stable low birthweight infants from the hospital, allowing continued care at home with close follow-up.

 

These components are fundamental to the success of KMC, leading to improved survival rates and health outcomes for low birthweight infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early discharge, skin to skin contact, prevent infection: Includes "prevent infection," which is an essential aspect of general neonatal care but not a specific component of KMC. KMC primarily focuses on skin-to-skin contact, breastfeeding, and early discharge.

 

Option C. Skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, prevent infection: Also mentions "prevent infection," which, while important, is not a direct component of KMC.

 

Option D. Early discharge, exclusive breastfeeding and prevent infection: Includes "prevent infection" instead of "skin-to-skin contact," making it incorrect, as skin-to-skin contact is a critical element of KMC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) involves skin-to-skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, and early discharge, focusing on the care of low birthweight infants.

questions.text: A 45-year-old banker presented with vague abdominal pain. On US, he was found to have a renal mass lesion. CECT was done, as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Renal angiomyolipoma

 

Explanation:

 

The CT image presented here shows well-circumscribed lesions with low attenuation (black in color) that indicate fatty tissue. The presence of macroscopic fat is strongly suggestive angiomyolipoma. The presence of macroscopic fat within the lesion, which results in negative Hounsfield units on CT, is a key diagnostic feature of angiomyolipoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RCC (Renal Cell Carcinoma): Typically appears as a solid mass that may be hypervascular and can show necrosis but does not characteristically contain macroscopic fat.

 

Option B. Renal oncocytoma: Usually presents as a well-circumscribed, solid mass with a central scar, which is not visible in this image.

 

Option D. Renal cyst: Would appear as a fluid-filled structure without solid components, typically with very clear borders and no internal complexity or enhancement.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following supplement is required more for a lactating woman than the pregnant female? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Vitamin A


During lactation, the mother's body requires additional nutrients to support breast milk production, which provides all necessary nutrients for the growing infant. Some nutrient needs increase more during lactation than pregnancy.

 

Comparison of Nutritional Requirements:

 

Vitamin A:

Needed for:

  • Infant vision development
  • Immune function
  • Epithelial integrity

Significantly increased loss through breast milk

Hence, greater requirement in lactation than pregnancy

 

Others options:


B12, Calcium, and Thiamine requirements increase only slightly or remain the same.

Vitamin A shows the most significant increase.

 

Educational Objective: 

Vitamin A is required more for a lactating woman than a pregnant female. This increased need ensures that there is enough vitamin A in breast milk to support the baby's growth and development, particularly for their immune system and vision.

questions.text: RBC uses which of the following substances during fasting/starvation? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucose

 

Under normal physiological conditions, RBCs rely on glucose as their main energy source. Glucose is metabolized through the glycolytic pathway within RBCs to produce ATP, which is essential for maintaining the structural and functional integrity of red blood cells. RBCs lack mitochondria, so they exclusively use anaerobic glycolysis to generate energy from glucose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ketones: RBCs do not utilize ketones as a significant energy source. Ketones are typically used by other tissues like the brain and muscles during prolonged fasting or starvation when glucose levels are low.

 

Option C. Amino acids: While amino acids can be used as an energy source by some tissues during fasting or starvation, RBCs primarily rely on glucose and do not extensively use amino acids for energy production.

 

Option D. Fatty acids: RBCs do not use fatty acids as their primary energy source during fasting or starvation. Fatty acid metabolism primarily occurs in tissues with mitochondria, and RBCs lack these organelles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RBCs always uses glucose whether it is fed state or fasting/starvation state because RBCs lack mitochondria. As ketone body utilization and fatty acid oxidation both take place in mitochondria so, RBCs cannot use fatty acids & ketone bodies as energy source.

 

Table: Substrates utilized for energy production

 

 

  • Fetal heart and also in case of heart failure, main fuel is Glucose.
  • Brain cannot use FA as FAs cannot cross blood brain barrier.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/p 138-139

questions.text: What is the most common route of the spread of retinoblastoma? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Direct invasion

 

Direct invasion is the most common mode of spread of retinoblastoma.

Direct invasion included the optic nerve and the other parts in contact with the tumour mass. Thus, Direct invasion is a better choice. 

 

  • Retinoblastoma is a malignancy that arises from the neurosensory retina.
  • It is the most common primary intraocular cancer in children.
  • Tumours are composed of small basophilic cells (retinoblasts), with large hyperchromatic nuclei and scanty cytoplasm.

 

There are four types of retinoblastomas:

 

  1. Endophytic (into the vitreous) with seeding of tumor cells throughout the eye
  2. Exophytic (into the subretinal space) leading to retinal detachment
  3. Mixed type
  4. Retinocytoma: retina may be diffusely infiltrated.

 

The child is usually brought to the surgeon on account of a peculiar yellowish-white reflex from the pupil, sometimes called leukocoria or amaurotic cat's eye.

 

 

Other modes of presentation include a convergent or divergent squint, cataract, buphthalmos, hypopyon, or proptosis.

 

If left untreated, retinoblastoma runs through the following stages:

 

  • The quiescent stage: lasting from 6 months to a year.
  • The glaucomatous stage: results in enlargement of the globe, with apparent or real proptosis. Pain is severe during this stage but is relieved when the tumor bursts through the sclera.
  • The stage of extraocular extension
  • The stage of metastasis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Optic nerve invasion: While possible, it is not the most common initial route of spread but is critical once involved, as it facilitates spread to the brain.

 

Option B. Hematogenous: Represents the method for distant metastasis rather than initial local spread.

 

Option D. Lymphatic spread: Uncommon in retinoblastoma since the eye lacks significant lymphatic channels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Direct invasion is the primary method of spread for retinoblastoma is essential in recognizing how the tumor progresses and impacts surrounding ocular structures. This knowledge is crucial for effective screening, early diagnosis, and management to prevent advanced stages of disease and potential metastasis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented with a history of bilateral lower limb weakness which progressed to his upper limbs in a year. On examination, he had weakness in both lower limbs and wasting in the left upper limb. Babinski sign was positive and the deep tendon reflexes were absent. He has no sensory loss or any autonomic dysfunction. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ALS


Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by mixed upper and lower motor neuron signs. The presence of both Babinski sign (an upper motor neuron sign) and absent deep tendon reflexes (a lower motor neuron sign), along with the chronic progression and lack of sensory/autonomic involvement, strongly points towards ALS.

 

Other Options:


Option A. MS: Multiple sclerosis typically involves sensory symptoms and demyelinating plaques visible on MRI, which are not described here.

 

Option C. GBS: Guillain-Barré Syndrome is an acute condition with a rapid onset and is primarily a lower motor neuron disease without upper motor neuron signs like the Babinski reflex.

 

Option D. Tropical spastic paraparesis: This condition is associated with HTLV-1 infection and presents predominantly with upper motor neuron signs, not the mixed signs seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ALS presents with both upper and lower motor neuron signs, progressive weakness, and no sensory or autonomic dysfunction.

questions.text: SAFE strategy for trachoma includes all except? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Evaluation of control program

 

In the SAFE strategy, ‘E’ stands for Environmental improvement with better hygiene and sanitation.

 

Effective interventions for trachoma blindness have been demonstrated in developing nations using the SAFE strategy –

 

  • Surgery (S): Performed to correct trichiasis, which is the inward turning of the eyelashes that can lead to corneal damage and blindness. This intervention helps prevent further damage to the cornea.
  • Antibiotics (A): Used to treat the infection caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. Mass drug administration is typically used in endemic areas to reduce the prevalence of the infection.
  • Facial cleanliness (F): Encouraged to reduce transmission of the bacterium among community members, especially children who are more susceptible to infection.
  • Environmental improvement (E): Focuses on improving living conditions, such as increasing access to clean water and better sanitation facilities, to reduce the spread of the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the following weapons with the possible injuries caused by them: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A-4, B-3, C-1, D-2

 

Mechanism of Injury with the Following Weapons:

 

A. Axe - 4. Chop wound: Axes are heavy and have a sharp edge, causing deep, gaping wounds that are classified as chop wounds.

 

B. RTA (Road Traffic Accident)- 3.Grazed abrasion: In RTAs, the skin may be scraped off, resulting in grazed abrasions due to friction against the road surface.

 

C. Blade- 1. Incised wound: Blades are sharp-edged tools that cause clean, sharp cuts known as incised wounds.

 

D. Lathi - 2. Tram track wound: A lathi, or baton, is a blunt object that can cause parallel linear bruises known as tram track wounds when struck with force.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mechanism of injury with the following weapons:

choices.text: Aspergillus Niger - Voriconazole
Aspergillus fumigatus - Micafungin
Candida albicans - Amphotericin B
Candida Krusei– Fluconazole

questions.text: Identify the correct 'organism-drug to which it is intrinsically resistant' pair: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Candida Krusei- Fluconazole

 

Candida Krusei is known to be intrinsically resistant to fluconazole, which is a widely used antifungal agent. This resistance is due to the specific genetic and biochemical characteristics of C. Kruse, which include efflux pumps that actively expel the drug and alterations in the target enzyme of fluconazole, making it less effective.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Aspergillus Niger - Voriconazole: Aspergillus Niger is not intrinsically resistant to voriconazole; in fact, voriconazole is one of the treatments of choice for Aspergillus infections.

 

Option B. Aspergillus fumigatus - Micafungin: Aspergillus fumigatus is sensitive to echinocandins, including micafungin. It is not intrinsically resistant to this drug.

 

Option C. Candida albicans - Amphotericin B: Candida albicans is sensitive to amphotericin B, which is a broad-spectrum antifungal with a wide range of activity against various fungal species.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candida Krusei is intrinsically resistant to fluconazole.

questions.text: Which of the following proteins of human papilloma virus inactivates Rb gene? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) E7

 

Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is associated with several cancers, including cervical cancer. HPV has two key oncoproteins, E6 and E7, that play a crucial role in the pathogenesis of cancer by inactivating tumor suppressor proteins.

 

E7 protein binds to and inactivates the Rb (Retinoblastoma) gene, which is a crucial tumor suppressor that controls cell cycle progression. By inactivating Rb, E7 disrupts the regulation of the cell cycle, leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation, a hallmark of cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E6: Targets and degrades p53 but does not inactivate Rb. E6 promotes the degradation of p53, leading to the loss of its tumor suppressor functions, such as apoptosis and DNA repair.

 

Option C. L1: L1 is a major capsid protein of HPV involved in the assembly of the viral particle but does not have a role in inactivating tumor suppressor genes.

 

Option D. L2: L2 is a minor capsid protein involved in viral genome packaging and entry into host cells but does not inactivate tumor suppressor genes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The E7 protein of Human Papillomavirus (HPV) inactivates the Rb gene, leading to disruption of the cell cycle and contributing to the development of cancer.

 

HPV Oncoproteins:

 

 

L1 protein is useful for making vaccine for HPV. (recent INICET ques)

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy was diagnosed with intussusception and is taken up for surgery. The surgeon found multiple polyps and sent the resected section for histopathology. The image is given below. What is the type of lesion? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hamartomatous polyp

 

The image and clinical scenario point towards a hamartomatous polyp, particularly because of the patient's young age and the finding of multiple polyps. Hamartomatous polyps are generally solitary lesions but can be multiple in certain syndromes, such as Peutz-Jeghers syndrome and juvenile polyposis syndrome, which are more common in children and adolescents.

 

Hamartomatous polyps are benign, disorganized growths of tissue that are normally found in the location where they arise. In the context of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, these polyps are associated with an increased risk of intussusception due to their size and location in the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tubulo-villous adenoma: This type of adenoma has both tubular and villous features and is typically found in older adults, with a higher risk of malignant transformation.

 

Option C. Villous Adenoma: These are the most dangerous types of adenomas due to their higher potential for malignancy, but they are usually seen in older patients and have a distinctive villous histological appearance.

 

Option D. Hyperplastic polyp: Generally benign and more common in adults, hyperplastic polyps are typically located in the distal colon and rectum and are not associated with intussusception or multiple polyps in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1557

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT involved in renal auto-regulation?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Renal sympathetic system fires

 

Renal autoregulation is important to maintain the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Blood flow to kidneys remains normal even when the mean arterial blood pressure very widely between 60 mm Hg and 180 mm Hg. This helps to maintain normal GFR.

 

Two mechanisms are involved in renal autoregulation:

 

  1. Myogenic response - mechanism that contributes to the maintenance of a relatively constant renal blood flow and GFR is the ability of individual blood vessels to resist stretching during increased arterial pressure
  2. Tubuloglomerular feedback via macula densa. Renin-angiotensin system also plays a role.

 

 

 

Macula densa feedback mechanism for autoregulation of glomerular hydrostatic pressure and glomerular filtration rate (GFR) during decreased renal arterial pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tubuloglomerular feedback: Incorrect. Tubuloglomerular feedback is a key component of renal autoregulation.

 

Option B. Myogenic reflex: Incorrect. The myogenic reflex is a crucial mechanism in renal autoregulation.

 

Option C. Renin-angiotensin system: Incorrect. The renin-angiotensin system supports renal autoregulation, particularly in adjusting the efferent arteriolar resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal autoregulation primarily involves the myogenic response and tubuloglomerular feedback mechanisms to maintain stable GFR. The renal sympathetic system, while involved in renal blood flow regulation, is not part of intrinsic autoregulation mechanisms.

questions.text: Which of the following emergency contraceptive is used in India? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg


In India, Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg is commonly used as an emergency contraceptive. This medication is effective when taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. It works primarily by inhibiting or delaying ovulation, thus preventing pregnancy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol 400 mcg: Incorrect. Misoprostol is used for medical abortion and does not serve as an emergency contraceptive.

 

Option B. Ethinyl estradiol 600 mcg: Incorrect. Ethinyl estradiol is used in combined oral contraceptive pills, but it is not commonly used alone for emergency contraception. The Yuzpe regimen, which includes ethynyl estradiol, is less commonly used compared to levonorgestrel.

 

Option C. Ulipristal 30 mg: Incorrect. Ulipristal acetate (30 mg) is a selective progesterone receptor modulator used as an emergency contraceptive, but it is not as widely available or commonly used in India as levonorgestrel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg is the emergency contraceptive used in India.

 

Ref: Page no 243, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th edition

choices.text: Toxoplasma gondii

questions.text: Identify the organism from the lifecycle shown in the image given below? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Toxoplasma gondii

 

The given image shows the lifecycle of Toxoplasma gondii.

 

Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite that causes toxoplasmosis.

 

Definitive hosts - Members of Felidae (domestic cats and their relatives). The enteric cycle occurs in definitive hosts.

 

Intermediate hosts in nature (including birds and rodents). Exoenteric cycle occurs in intermediate hosts such as humans, mice, rats, etc.

 

Life cycle of toxoplasma gondii

 

  1. Unsporulated oocysts are shed in the cat’s feces. Although oocysts are usually only shed for 1–3 weeks, large numbers may be shed.
  2. Oocysts take 1–5 days to sporulate in the environment and become infective. Intermediate hosts in nature (including birds and rodents) become infected after ingesting soil, water or plant material contaminated with oocysts.
  3. Oocysts transform into tachyzoites shortly after ingestion. These tachyzoites localize in neural and muscle tissue and develop into tissue cyst bradyzoites.
  4. Cats become infected after consuming intermediate hosts harboring tissue cysts. Cats may also become infected directly by ingestion of sporulated oocysts.
  5. Animals bred for human consumption and wild game may also become infected with tissue cysts after ingestion of sporulated oocysts in the environment.

 

Humans can become infected by any of several routes:

 

  • Eating undercooked meat of animals harboring tissue cysts
  • Consuming food or water contaminated with cat feces or by contaminated environmental samples (such as fecal-contaminated soil or changing the litter box of a pet cat).
  • Blood transfusion or organ transplantation.
  • Transplacentally from mother to fetus.
  • In the human host, the parasites form tissue cysts, most commonly in skeletal muscle, myocardium, brain, and eyes; these cysts may remain throughout the life of the host.

 

 

Diagnosis is usually achieved by serology, although tissue cysts may be observed in stained biopsy specimens.

 

Diagnosis of congenital infections can be achieved by detecting T. gondii DNA in amniotic fluid using molecular methods such as PCR

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Cystoisospora: Causes isosporiasis, primarily affecting the gastrointestinal tract. Its lifecycle involves humans as the definitive host.

 

Option B. Cryptosporidium: Causes cryptosporidiosis, an intestinal illness. The lifecycle involves direct fecal-oral transmission.

 

Option C. Plasmodium knowlesi: Causes malaria, with a lifecycle involving mosquitoes as vectors and humans as host.

 

Educational Objective

 

Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite with a complex lifecycle involving cats as definitive hosts and various animals, including humans, as intermediate hosts. The lifecycle stages, including oocysts and tissue cysts, are crucial for transmission and infection.

choices.text: Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the ER after falling off a horse. Her vitals are stable, but she complains of pain and tenderness in her lower abdomen and has not passed urine yet. On examination, there is a visible bruise over her lower abdomen, and blood is seen at the urethral meatus. The bladder is not palpable. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy

 

The most appropriate initial management option for a patient with a possible bladder injury is Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy.

 

Trauma to lower abdomen with blood at urethral meatus implies urethral rupture. The most appropriate initial management option for a patient with a possible urethral injury is Wait for the bladder to fill and then do a suprapubic cystostomy.

 

After bladder fills up with urine, a suprapubic cystostomy is done in immediate management of urethral rupture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wait and send her home: This option is not appropriate for a patient with a possible urethral injury.

 

Option B. Immediate insertion of Foley catheter: This option involves the insertion of a small tube through the urethra and into the bladder to drain urine. This is contraindicated in suspected urethral rupture, as it may create false passage.

 

Option C. Suprapubic aspiration of urine: This option involves inserting a needle through the skin and into the bladder to aspirate urine. This option may be preferred in cases where the urethra is injured or obstructed, making the insertion of a Foley catheter difficult. For this to be done, the bladder should be distended.

questions.text: What is the structure marked in the CT scan? (INCET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anterior ethmoidal canal  

 

Explanation:

 

Anterior ethmoidal canal is noted by the marked arrows. The anterior ethmoidal canal can be recognized by the fact that it lies below the ethmoidal air cell roof. To prevent bleeding from this vessel during sinus procedures, it is crucial to recognize that the anterior ethmoidal artery runs via this canal. Maxillary sinus is noted in this view hence suggesting anterior plane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The posterior ethmoidal artery, vein, and nerve pass via the ethmoid bone’s posterior ethmoid canal or foramen. Due to the fact that this image is a coronal section taken at the level of the anterior ethmoidal cells, it cannot be seen.

 

Option C. The optic nerve can be identified as an oval intraorbital structure in the coronal sections.

 

Option D. The cribriform plate is a sieve-like structure between the nasal cavity and the anterior cranial fossa. It is part of the ethmoid bone and as it is pierced by the olfactory nerve fibers. Crista Galli is also a part of ethmoid bone that projects superiorly from the cribriform plate. It provides attachment for the falx cerebri.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior ethmoidal canal is critical to identify during sinus procedures to avoid complications such as bleeding from the anterior ethmoidal artery. It is located below the roof of the ethmoidal air cells and anterior to the posterior ethmoidal canal.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used to treat PCOD? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tamoxifen

 

Explanation:

 

Tamoxifen is not commonly used in the treatment of Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD). Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) primarily used in the treatment and prevention of breast cancer.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Medical Management of PCOD:
    • OCP (Option D): Oral contraceptive pills regulate the menstrual cycle and hormones and are given to women who are not desirous of fertility to regularize their cycles.
    • Metformin (Option B): Metformin is an insulin sensitizer, which decreases hyperinsulinemia and improves fertility in patients with PCOD.
    • Ovulation Induction Drugs:
      • Clomiphene (Option A): Clomiphene citrate is commonly used to induce ovulation in women with infertility due to PCOD.
      • Letrozole: Letrozole, an aromatase inhibitor, is the drug of choice for ovulation induction in PCOD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clomiphene citrate: Clomiphene is an ovulation induction agent used in the treatment of infertility in women with PCOD.

 

Option B. Metformin: Metformin is used to decrease insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia in PCOD, which can help in regulating menstrual cycles and improving fertility.

 

Option D. OCP: Oral contraceptive pills are used to regulate menstrual cycles and manage hormonal imbalances in women with PCOD who do not seek to become pregnant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tamoxifen is not typically used in the treatment of PCOD. Instead, treatments include oral contraceptive pills, metformin, and ovulation induction agents such as clomiphene and letrozole.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition. Pg 398 Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg470

questions.text: What is the cause of the lesion shown in the image below?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lightning strike

 

The image shows fern-like patterns, known as Lichtenberg flowers or filigree burns, which are characteristic of lightening injury.

 

Filigree burns:

 

  • Also called Arborescent or Lichtenberger’s flowers
  • They pathognomonic feature of lightening
  • Superficial, thin, irregular and tortuous markings on skin like branches of tree (fern like pattern).
  • They are caused by Slight staining of tissues by hemoglobin from lysed red blood cells (from superficial capillaries) along the path of electric current. Hence, they indicate the path taken by the discharge.
  • They do not follow the path of major blood vessels, but only follow the superficial capillaries
  • Though called Filigree Burns but they are not actually burns
  • They are transient erythema which appears within a few minutes to 1 hour of accident and gradually fades within 24 – 48 hours if the person survives.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Electrocution: Electrocution typically causes electrical burns which are different from the filigree burns seen in lightning strikes. These burns are usually deep and may show entry and exit wounds.

 

Option C. Marbling: Marbling refers to a postmortem change where blood vessels become visible as greenish-black streaks on the skin, occurring due to decomposition and is not related to electrical injuries.

 

Option D. Trickling down of acid: Acid injuries typically cause chemical burns with distinct, often more severe damage to the skin and tissues, and do not produce the characteristic fern-like patterns seen in lightning strikes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Filigree burns or Lichtenberg flowers are pathognomonic for lightning strikes and appear as superficial, fern-like patterns on the skin that fade within 24-48 hours.

choices.text: Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, HBV, Injectable Polio
Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Haemophilus influenza B, Pneumococcal vaccine
Diphtheria, Tetanus, HBV, Haemophilus influenza B, Pertussis

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic for her first round of vaccinations. The mother is anxious and wants to ensure her child receives all the necessary immunizations. You explain that one of the shots the child will receive is the Pentavalent vaccine, which combines five different immunizations into a single injection. Which of the following immunizations are combined in the Pentavalent vaccine? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diphtheria, Tetanus, HBV, Haemophilus influenza B, Pertussis

 

  • Pentavalent vaccine consists of five vaccines - Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Hepatitis B and Haemophilus Influenzae Type B (Hib).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

NEW National Immunization Schedule (NIS) 2023-24

questions.text: What is the most common tumor of the lacrimal gland? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pleomorphic adenoma

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the lacrimal gland. This tumor is composed of a mix of ductal and myoepithelial cells, often presenting as a painless, progressive, firm mass typically located in the superolateral aspect of the orbit.

 

Details about Pleomorphic Adenoma:

 

  • Benign Nature: Despite its benign nature, pleomorphic adenoma can cause displacement of the eye and may alter vision due to its size and location.
  • Potential for Malignant Transformation: While it is primarily benign, there is a risk for malignant transformation into a carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma if not adequately treated or if left untreated for a long duration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoid cystic carcinoma: Although this is the most common malignant tumor of the lacrimal gland, it is not as frequently occurring as pleomorphic adenoma. Adenoid cystic carcinoma is known for its aggressive nature and poorer prognosis.

 

Option B. Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma: This type of tumor can involve the lacrimal gland but is generally less common than pleomorphic adenoma.

 

Option D. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma: This is another type of malignant tumor that can occur in the lacrimal gland, but it is also less common than pleomorphic adenoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the lacrimal gland while adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common malignant tumour of the lacrimal gland. Overall, benign tumours are more common, thus pleomorphic adenoma is the most common lacrimal gland tumour.

questions.text: What type of MRI image is given below? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B Susceptibility weighted image

 

Explanation:

 

Susceptibility weighted imaging (SWI) is an MRI sequence which is sensitive to compounds that can distort the local magnetic field.

 

Type of Gradient echo sequence / T2* sequence 

 

Black dots s/o hemorrhage known as blooming

 

Sequence of choice for DAI (diffuse axonal injury)   

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proton density image: Typically used to provide good anatomical detail and contrast of soft tissues, not specifically sensitive to magnetic susceptibilities.

 

Option C. Gradient echo image: While SWI uses gradient echo sequences, it specifically exploits phase data and magnitude data to enhance the visibility of substances affecting magnetic susceptibility.

 

Option D. Inversion recovery image: This MRI technique is used to suppress or enhance certain tissue types based on their relaxation properties, which is not indicative of the contrast seen in this image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Susceptibility weighted imaging (SWI) is particularly useful in detecting and differentiating substances in the brain that affect magnetic susceptibility, such as iron and blood, making it an excellent choice for identifying microhemorrhages and assessing diffuse axonal injury.

questions.text: Binding site of miRNA on mRNA?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3’ UTR

 

  • This is the correct option.
  • miRNA binds to the 3' UTR of mRNA, leading to translational repression or mRNA degradation, thereby regulating gene expression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5’ UTR (Untranslated Region):

  • This region is not typically the binding site for miRNA on mRNA.
  • miRNA primarily binds to the 3' UTR of mRNA to regulate gene expression.

 

Option C. Gene Promoter:

  • Gene promoters are regions involved in transcription initiation, not the binding sites for miRNA.

 

Option D.  Gene Body:

  • miRNA primarily targets the 3' UTR of mRNA, not the gene body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The binding site of miRNA on mRNA is typically the 3’ UTR (Untranslated Region), where miRNA can regulate gene expression by binding and influencing mRNA stability or translation.

 

Ref - Lehninger 6th e/p 1081

questions.text: The 20-year-old young female presented to the OPD with the following forehead lesions. Which of the following methods won't help with the treatment of various stages of this condition? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Topical fluocinolone

 

The patient's age and the presence of comedones on the face are suggestive of acne. With the exception of topical fluocinolone (a topical steroid), all of the aforementioned treatments are effective for treating acne. Regardless of how they are administered (Topical or oral).

 

Topical fluocinolone is a corticosteroid. While it may reduce inflammation, its use is not recommended for acne as it can exacerbate the condition, potentially causing acneiform eruption or steroid acne. Steroids can also lead to skin thinning and other adverse effects when used on the face for extended periods.

 

  • Acne is a chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit. Comedonal lesions are the Earliest lesions of acne,
  • They represent the keratin plugs of the pilosebaceous duct.
  • When the keratin plug is inside the follicle, it is called a closed comedones or whitehead.
  • When the keratin plug is exposed to the environment, it gets oxidized by the air & turns black which is known as open comedones (blackhead).

 

Stages of acne:

 

 

Global alliance algorithm for acne treatment

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Topical benzoyl peroxide:

 

  • This is a commonly used treatment for acne. Its mechanism of action includes reducing Propionibacterium acnes (a bacteria contributing to acne) colonization and producing an oxidizing effect which reduces inflammation.
  • It is effective and is commonly used either alone or in combination with other treatments.

 

Option C. Topical tazarotene:

 

  • Tazarotene is a topical retinoid. Retinoids are vitamin A derivatives that help unclog pores by promoting the shedding of dead skin cells from the surface of the skin and reducing inflammation.
  • They are effective in treating both non-inflammatory and inflammatory acne lesions.

 

Option D. Topical antibiotics:

 

  • These help in reducing the P. acnes bacterial count, which subsequently reduces inflammation.
  • Commonly used topical antibiotics include clindamycin and Nadifloxacin.
  • They may be used alone or in combination with other agents, such as benzoyl peroxide, to reduce bacterial resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Topical fluocinolone, a corticosteroid, can reduce inflammation, but it is not recommended for acne treatment as it can exacerbate the condition.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 90 page no 90.1-90.37

choices.text: Half-life doubles and plasma concentration remains the same
Half-life remains the same and plasma concentration doubles
Half-life and plasma concentration remains the same
Half-life and plasma concentration doubles

questions.text: What would happen to the half-life and plasma concentration of a drug which follows first-order kinetics, if the dose is doubled? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Half-life remains the same and plasma concentration doubles
 

In case of drugs following 1st order kinetics, a constant fraction of the drug is eliminated in a given time. Therefore, the half-life of the drug remains constant and the Clearance also remains constant.

 

Key points regarding first-order kinetics:

 

  • Half-life remains constant: The half-life of the drug does not change with the dose. It remains constant because the fraction of the drug eliminated per unit time is constant.
  • Clearance remains constant: The clearance, which is the volume of plasma from which the drug is completely removed per unit time, remains constant.
  • Plasma concentration: When the dose is doubled, the plasma concentration of the drug also doubles because the rate of elimination is proportional to the concentration of the drug in the plasma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For drugs following first-order kinetics, The rate of elimination of the drug is directly proportional its plasma concentration. So, when the dose is doubled for a drug following first order kinetics, the plasma concentration is also doubled.

questions.text: A couple presents to the infertility clinic with a normal hysterosalpingogram and a semen analysis report with azoospermia. Which of the following test is useful to differentiate between an obstructive and a testicular cause? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Testicular Biopsy

 

Explanation:

 

  • The absence of sperm in semen is known as azoospermia. It can be due to:
    • Pre-testicular azoospermia due to a hypothalamic or pituitary abnormality (hypogonadotropic hypogonadism)
    • Testicular failure or non-obstructive azoospermia
    • Post-testicular obstruction implies normal spermatogenesis but failure to deliver the sperm into the ejaculate because of ducal obstruction.
  • In testicular cause of azoospermia, there will be absent or very few sperms on biopsy whereas in obstructive azoospermia, there will be normal sperms on biopsy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum FSH levels and Option B. Serum testosterone levels are important for spermatogenesis

 

  • FSH levels can be used to differentiate hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism from other causes of testicular failure

 

Option D. Serum LH level: LH is a non-specific test in evaluation of azoospermia

 

Educational Objective:

 

A testicular biopsy is useful to differentiate between an obstructive and a testicular cause of Azoospermia.

 

Ref: Page no 233, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6the edition

questions.text: Through which of the following marked sites does SARS-COVID 19 spread to the brain? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A

 

Explanation:

 

The structures marked in the given image are :

 

  1. Cribriform plate
  2. Foramen ovale
  3. Optic canal
  4. Foramen lacerum

 

The cribriform plate, marked as "A" in the image, is recognized as one of the potential entry routes for the SARS-CoV-2 virus to access the brain. The cribriform plate forms the roof of the nasal cavity and has small holes through which the olfactory nerves pass.

 

The virus can potentially enter the olfactory bulbs situated above the cribriform plate, which are directly connected to the nasal cavity. This provides a pathway for the virus to spread from the upper respiratory tract to the olfactory nerve endings (as well as dissemination through trans-synaptic transfer) and subsequently to the brain, potentially leading to neurological manifestations.

 

Encephalitis, demyelination, neuropathy, and stroke are the neurological sequelae to severe COVID-19 infection. The neurological invasion of the virus on the medullary cardiorespiratory center can lead to refractory respiratory failure in patients infected with COVID-19.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A (D - Foramen Lacerum): Mainly filled with cartilage and does not transmit major nerves or blood vessels that could carry infections into the cranial cavity.

 

Option B (C - Optic Canal): Serves as the passage for the optic nerve from the eye to the brain, but not a known route for SARS-CoV-2 entry into the brain.

 

Option C (B - Foramen Ovale): A passage for the mandibular nerve, part of the trigeminal nerve, which has no established connection to SARS-CoV-2 neuroinvasion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cribriform plate is a plausible pathway for SARS-CoV-2 to access the brain due to its direct connection to the nasal cavity and olfactory system. Understanding these potential routes is crucial for comprehending the broader impact of the virus on the nervous system.

choices.text: Beta Glucocerebrosidase - Von Gierke’s
Ceruloplasmin - Hepatolenticular degeneration
High LDH1/LDH2 - Myocardial Infarction
Lipase - Pancreatitis

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes/diagnostic marker is incorrectly paired?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta Glucocerebrosidase - Von Gierke’s

 

Option A. Defect in Beta glucocerebrosidase is associated with sphingolipid lysosomal storage disorder known as Gaucher’s disease Whereas Von Gierke’s disease is caused due to deficiency of enzyme Glucose-6-phosphatase.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Hepatolenticular degeneration also known as Wilson’s disease is due to defect in ATP7B gene causing defective biliary excretion of copper and accumulation of copper in liver. There is decrease in plasma ceruloplasmin serving as marker.

 

Option C. In normal person, LDH-2 is more than LDH-1 in serum. BUT in myocardial infarction, LDH-1>>LDH-2. This is known as Flipped ratio of LDH in Myocardial Infarction.

 

Option D. Lipase and amylase are increased in plasma in case of Pancreatitis hence they serve as marker enzymes for pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective

 

Beta-glucocerebrosidase is linked to Gaucher’s disease, not Von Gierke’s disease, which is caused by a deficiency in Glucose-6-phosphatase. Correct pairing of diagnostic markers and associated conditions is crucial for accurate diagnosis.

 

Ref - Harper 31st e/p 64, 167,634

questions.text: Positive charge in thick ascending loop of Henle is maintained by recirculation of which cation: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) K+

 

In the thick ascending loop of Henle, the maintenance of positive charge is primarily achieved through the recirculation of potassium ions (K+).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. H+ (Hydrogen ions): Hydrogen ions play a role in regulating the pH of urine but are not primarily responsible for maintaining positive charge in the thick ascending loop of Henle.

 

Option B. Na+ (Sodium ions): Sodium ions are actively reabsorbed in the thick ascending loop of Henle but are not the primary cation responsible for maintaining positive charge in this segment.

 

Option C. NH4+ (Ammonium ions): Ammonium ions are involved in acid-base regulation in the kidneys but are not the primary cation responsible for maintaining positive charge in the thick ascending loop of Henle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thick ascending loop of Henle (TAL) is impermeable to water but there is active reabsorption of Na, Cl and K. The cotransporter in membrane of TAL is responsible for reabsorption of 1/3 of both Na and Cl in the body. On the basolateral side there is Na/K ATPase pump which throws sodium out and K in. This K+ is transported back into lumen through Renal outer medullary K+ channel (ROMK) channel for it to be recirculated.

 

 

Ref- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4220766/

questions.text: A patient came to be emergency department with a radiograph showing posterior dislocation of hip. No associated fractures are seen. What is the next step in management? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closed reduction

 

POSTERIOR DISLOCATION OF THE HIP

 

  • The head of the femur is pushed out of the acetabulum posteriorly. 
  • It is more common (90%)
  • Mechanism of injury:
    • The injury is sustained by violence directed along the shaft of the femur, with the hip flexed.
    • The occupant of the car is thrown forwards and his knee strikes against the dashboard. 
    • The axial load applied on a flexed knee placed in adduction.
    • The force is transmitted up the femoral shaft, resulting in posterior dislocation of the hip. It is, therefore, also known as dashboard injury.

 

 

  • Clinical features: 
    • The patient presents with a history of severe trauma followed by pain, swelling and deformity (flexion, adduction and internal rotation – FADIR), associated with a shortening of the leg.

 

 

  • Radiological features: 
    • The femoral head is out of the acetabulum. 

 

 

  • The thigh is internally rotated so that the lesser trochanter is not seen. Shenton’s line is broken.

 

  • Treatment:
    • In most cases, it is possible to reduce the hip by closed manipulation under general anaesthesia. 
    • Closed reduction is the primary and most urgent step in the management of an acute traumatic hip dislocation without associated contraindications. 
    • The sooner the reduction, the lower the risk of complications like AVN. 
    • Open reduction may be required in cases where:
      • Closed reduction fails, usually in those presenting late
      • If there is intra-articular loose fragment not allowing accurate reduction
      • If the acetabular fragment is large and is from the weight-bearing part of the acetabulum. Such a fragment makes the hip unstable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open reduction. Open reduction is done when closed reduction fails, usually in patients presenting late OR if there is an intra-articular loose fragment not allowing accurate reduction OR if the acetabular fragment is large and is from the weight bearing part of the acetabulum. Since the question states "No associated fractures are seen," and it's an acute presentation, open reduction is not the first line.

 

Option C. NCCT pelvis: A CT scan is very useful after closed reduction to check for concentric reduction, identify any occult fractures not seen on plain X-rays (especially small intra-articular fragments or acetabular wall fractures), and assess for incarceration of fragments. However, it is not the immediate next step before reduction in an uncomplicated dislocation, as delaying reduction to get a CT increases the risk of AVN. The priority is to reduce the hip.

 

Option D. Arthroplasty. Hip replacement surgery can be considered if optimal stability is not achieved with reduction and fixation of the associated injuries. It is a definitive surgical procedure, usually performed for severe arthritis or irreparable damage. It is definitely not the immediate next step for an acute hip dislocation in a patient who likely has no pre-existing severe joint disease and no associated fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment of choice for posterior dislocations of hip is closed reduction/manipulation under general anesthesia in cases with no associated fractures.

questions.text:
Which of the following modalities are used for the diagnosis of placenta accreta? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Ultrasonography
  2. MRI
  3. Angiography
  4. X-ray
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 2 only

 

Explanation:


Ultrasonography and MRI are key modalities used in the diagnosis of placenta accreta.

 

  • Ultrasonography (1): This is often the first imaging modality used to diagnose placenta accreta. It helps in visualizing the placental attachment and identifying abnormalities in placental implantation. Color Doppler ultrasonography is particularly useful to assess the blood flow and the vascularity of the placenta, which can indicate abnormal adherence.
  • MRI (2): MRI is used as a complementary imaging tool when ultrasonography results are inconclusive or to provide a more detailed view. It helps in evaluating the depth of placental invasion into the myometrium and can differentiate between placenta accreta, increta, and percreta.
  • Angiography (3): While angiography can provide information about blood vessels and may be used in some cases to evaluate blood flow abnormalities, it is not typically a primary diagnostic tool for placenta accreta. It may be used in specific scenarios or to plan surgical management, but it is not generally used for initial diagnosis.
  • X-ray (4): X-rays are not used in the diagnosis of placenta accreta due to their lack of sensitivity for soft tissue detail and the potential risk to the fetus. X-rays are not helpful in visualizing the placenta or its adherence to the uterine wall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Incorrect because it includes Angiography, which is not commonly used for the initial diagnosis of placenta accreta.

 

Option C: Incorrect because it includes Angiography, which is not a primary diagnostic tool for placenta accreta, and it excludes Ultrasonography, which is crucial for diagnosis.

 

Option D: Incorrect because X-ray is not used for diagnosing placenta accreta and does not contribute to the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:


Ultrasonography and MRI are the primary modalities used for diagnosing placenta accreta.

 

Ref: Page no 1982, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Identify the type of marked chromosome in the given karyotype? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acrocentric

 

Explanation:

 

The marked chromosome is chromosome 13 and the type is acrocentric.

 

Each chromatid has a long arm “q” and a short arm “p” which are separated by a centromere.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Metacentric: Metacentric chromosomes have the centromere located in the center, creating arms of equal length. Examples include chromosomes 1 and 3.

 

Option C. Submetacentric: Submetacentric chromosomes have the centromere slightly off-center, creating one long arm and one short arm. Most human autosomes and the X chromosome are submetacentric.

 

Option D. Telocentric: Telocentric chromosomes have the centromere at the very end of the chromosome, creating only one arm. This type is not present in humans.

 

Educational Objective

 

Chromosomes are classified based on the position of the centromere as follows:

questions.text: The stroke volume depends on end-diastolic volume. This is best represented as?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Length-tension relationship

 

The relationship between end-diastolic volume and stroke volume is best represented by length-tension relationship.

 

Frank-Starling mechanism states that the greater the heart muscle is stretched during filling, the greater is the force of contraction and the greater the quantity of blood pumped into the aorta or, stated another way: Within physiologic limits, the heart pumps all the blood that returns to it by the way of the veins.

 

When an extra amount of blood flows into the ventricles, the cardiac muscle itself is stretched to greater length. This in turn causes the muscle to contract with increased force because the actin and myosin filaments are brought to a more nearly optimal degree of overlap for force generation. Therefore, the ventricle, because of its increased pumping, automatically pumps the extra blood into the arteries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The relationship between end-diastolic volume and stroke volume in the heart is best described by the length-tension relationship, which underlies the Frank-Starling mechanism. This principle explains how increased filling of the heart leads to greater contraction force and increased stroke volume.

choices.text: Block sodium channels
Block potassium channels
Block calcium channels
Block chloride channels

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of local anesthetics?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Block sodium channels

 

  • Mechanism: Local anesthetics primarily act by blocking the sodium channels bound to the membrane of the nerve, thus inhibiting sodium influx into the nerve and avoiding depolarization of the nerve.
  • States of Sodium Channels: The voltage-gated sodium channels exist in three states:
    • Resting (non-conducting)
    • Open (conducting)
    • Inactivated (non-conducting)
  • Affinity: Local anesthetics have maximum affinity for the sodium channels in the inactivated state.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Block potassium channels:

Blocking potassium channels is not the primary mechanism of action for local anesthetics. Potassium channels are more involved in the repolarization phase of the action potential.

 

Option C. Block calcium channels:

Blocking calcium channels is not the primary mechanism of action for local anesthetics. Calcium channels are more involved in neurotransmitter release at synapses.

 

Option D. Block chloride channels:

Blocking chloride channels is not the primary mechanism of action for local anesthetics. Chloride channels are typically associated with inhibitory neurotransmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Local anesthetics work by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels, which prevents the influx of sodium ions into nerve cells, thereby inhibiting nerve depolarization and the propagation of action potentials.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 871

choices.text: Epithelial cell tumor
Germ cell tumor

questions.text: Which class of ovarian tumor does clear cell carcinoma of the ovary belong to? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epithelial cell tumor

 

Explanation:


Clear cell carcinoma of the ovary is classified under epithelial cell tumors. Epithelial ovarian tumors originate from the cells that line the surface of the ovary. Clear cell carcinoma is a subtype of epithelial ovarian tumors.

 

Classification of ovarian tumors:

 

  1. Epithelial Cell Tumor
    • Serous
    • Mucinous
    • Brenner
    • Clear cell
    • Endometrioid
    • Clear cell carcinoma falls under this category.
  2. Germ Cell Tumor
    • Dysgerminoma
    • Yolk sac tumor
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma
    • Embryonal
    • Clear cell carcinoma is not classified here.
  3. Sex Cord Stromal Tumor
    • Granulosa cell tumor
    • Thecoma
    • Fibroma
    • Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor
    • Clear cell carcinoma is not included in this category.

 

Educational Objective:


Clear cell carcinoma of the ovary is classified as an epithelial cell tumor.

 

Ref: Page no 291, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition
