choices.text: Methylene blue - malachite green - acetic acid-water

questions.text: A 32-year-old laborer working at a construction site presented with fever and hemoptysis. The sputum sample collected for examination showed the following. The smear will be stained by which of the following sequences? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Carbol fuschin - acid-alcohol - methylene blue

 

Clinical history along with microscopic picture is suggestive of mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. Microphotograph is of TB bacillus, Mycobacterium tuberculosis on an oil-immersion smear slide stained with Ziehl-Neelsen or acid-fast staining of a clinical sample. Bacilli are long and rod-shaped; a bacillus is indicated by a black arrow. Acid-fast bacilli are bright red after staining.

 

The Ziehl-Neelsen staining technique is a differential staining technique that was initially developed by Ziehl and modified later by Neelsen, hence the name Ziehl-Neelsen stain.

 

Reagent used in Ziehl Neelson stain are-

 

  • Carbol-Fuschin (Primary dye)
  • 20% sulphuric acid or acid-alcohol (Decolorizer)
  • Methylene Blue dye (counterstain) or malachite green

 

The use of acid-alcohol in the technique earned it the name Acid-Fast Stain and the application of heat in the technique gives it the name the hot method of Acid-Fast staining

 

Mycobacterium, Nocardia, Isospora, Cryptosporidium, and some fungi contain a thick cell wall made up of lipoidal complexes known as mycolic acid.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gentian violet - iodine - alcohol - safranin: This sequence is used for Gram staining, not for acid-fast bacilli.

 

Option B. Methylene blue - malachite green - acetic acid - water: This sequence is not used for any standard bacterial staining protocol.

 

Option C. Methanol - methylene blue - acid - water: This sequence does not correspond to the Ziehl-Neelsen stain or any other standard staining protocol for acid-fast bacilli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ziehl-Neelsen staining method, involving carbol fuschin, acid-alcohol, and methylene blue, is used to identify Mycobacterium tuberculosis in clinical samples. This technique highlights acid-fast bacilli, which retain the red color of carbol fuschin even after decolorization with acid-alcohol.

questions.text:
All of the following statements about proto-oncogenes are true except? (AIIMS MAY 2021)

 

  1. BRCA1 is an oncogene.
  2. HER2neu is amplified only in a fraction of breast cancer.
  3. EGFR (+) is seen in non-small cell lung cancer.
  4. N-MYC is a tumor suppressor gene.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 4

 

Statement 1: BRCA1 is an oncogene.


This is false. BRCA1 is not an oncogene; it is a tumor suppressor gene. Mutations in BRCA1 are associated with an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancers, but its normal function is to help repair DNA damage, thereby preventing cancer formation.

 

Statement 4: N-MYC is a tumor suppressor gene.


This is false. N-MYC is not a tumor suppressor gene; it is a proto-oncogene. N-MYC is involved in the regulation of cell growth and division. Amplification of the N-MYC gene is commonly seen in neuroblastoma and small-cell carcinoma of the lung.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2: HER2neu is amplified only in a fraction of breast cancer.


This is true. HER2 (also known as ERBB2) is a proto-oncogene that is amplified in approximately 15-20% of breast cancers. This amplification leads to overexpression of the HER2 protein, which promotes cell proliferation and survival.

 

Statement 3: EGFR (+) is seen in non-small cell lung cancer.


This is true. EGFR (Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor) is often overexpressed or mutated in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), leading to uncontrolled cell growth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BRCA1 is a tumor suppressor gene (involved in DNA repair) and N-MYC is a proto-oncogene (associated with development of neuroblastoma).

 

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition 521-528

questions.text: A researcher is examining the relationship between height and weight in a specific population. She decides to utilize a cluster sampling method to streamline the data collection process. After analyzing data from four distinct clusters, each one consistently demonstrates a correlation coefficient of 0.6 between height and weight. Based on this information, what can the researcher expect about the overall correlation coefficient when combining data from all four clusters? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Equal to 0.6

 

  • When each cluster independently shows a correlation coefficient of 0.6 between height and weight, the overall correlation coefficient for the combined data will also be 0.6.
  • This is because the correlation coefficient measures the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two variables, and consistent values across clusters will result in the same overall correlation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SCATTER/DOT DIAGRAM

 

  • Also known as ‘Correlation diagram
  • Is used to depict ‘correlation (relationship) between 2 quantitative variables
  • Vertical axis in scatter diagram: should be the dependent or the outcome variable
  • In a scatter diagram, 2 imaginary lines are drawn along the distribution of dots/ scatter.

questions.text: Which of the following feature is correct on the basis of given karyotype? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gynecomastia and long limbs

 

Given karyotyping image shows '47, XXY' abnormality, which is seen in Klinefelter's syndrome.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flat occiput: This feature is typically seen in Down syndrome (Trisomy 21).

 

Option C. Webbing of neck and lymphedema: These are characteristic features of Turner syndrome (45, X).

 

Option D. Short stature and polydactyly: These are features seen in Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Klinefelter syndrome (47, XXY) is characterized by gynecomastia, long limbs, small testes, and infertility.

 

Ref: Robbins and cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 316-317

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with hypertension is diagnosed with stage 4 chronic kidney disease, with eGFR of <30. His doctor wants to prescribe a thiazide diuretic. Which of the following can be given? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Metolazone

 

In the context of a patient with stage 4 chronic kidney disease (CKD) and an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of less than 30 mL/min, the choice of diuretic is important, as not all diuretics are effective in patients with significantly reduced kidney function. Among the thiazides, metolazone remains effective in presence of severe renal failure whereas traditional thiazides like chlorthalidone, hydrochlorothiazide and chlorthiazide are ineffective.

 

The reason Metolazone remains effective in patients with advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD), where traditional thiazide diuretics are less effective, lies in their pharmacokinetic properties and the way they interact with kidney function.

 

Site of Action and Kidney Function:

 

  • Thiazide diuretics primarily act on the distal convoluted tubule in the kidney. They inhibit the sodium-chloride symporter, leading to increased excretion of sodium and chloride, and consequently, water.
  • In advanced CKD, particularly when the eGFR (estimated glomerular filtration rate) falls below 30 mL/min, the kidney function is significantly impaired. Traditional thiazides become less effective because they depend on adequate kidney function to reach their site of action and to exert their diuretic effect.

 

Pharmacokinetics of Metolazone:

 

  • Metolazone is classified as a thiazide-like diuretic. Unlike traditional thiazides, it retains its effectiveness even in patients with reduced kidney function.
  • This is because metolazone has additional actions on the proximal tubule of the kidney, where it inhibits sodium reabsorption. This proximal action is not as dependent on kidney function as the action in the distal tubule.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chlorothiazide: This traditional thiazide diuretic is ineffective in patients with significantly reduced kidney function (eGFR <30 mL/min).

 

Option B. Chlorthalidone: Another traditional thiazide diuretic that is not effective in advanced CKD due to its reliance on adequate kidney function to exert its diuretic effect.

 

Option D. Hydrochlorothiazide: Like other traditional thiazides, hydrochlorothiazide is ineffective in patients with severe renal impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metolazone is the preferred thiazide-like diuretic for patients with stage 4 chronic kidney disease and an eGFR of less than 30 mL/min, as it retains its effectiveness even in the presence of significantly reduced kidney function. This is due to its additional action on the proximal tubule, which is less dependent on kidney function.

choices.text: Increase the dose
Decrease the dose
Stop the drug
Stop retigabine and start on carbamazepine

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with epilepsy was put on retigabine thrice a day. Now phenytoin is being added. Which of the following changes should be made to retigabine therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Increase the dose

 

In the scenario where phenytoin is added to a patient's epilepsy treatment regimen that already includes retigabine, and if one of the provided options must be chosen, the most appropriate choice, based on known pharmacological interactions, would be:

 

  • The rationale for this choice is based on the enzyme-inducing properties of phenytoin. Phenytoin is known to induce hepatic enzymes that metabolize many drugs, potentially leading to reduced levels of these drugs. The general principle of enzyme induction suggests that the levels of retigabine could be decreased when phenytoin is added. Therefore, an increase in the dose of retigabine may be necessary to maintain therapeutic drug levels and effective seizure control.
  • However, it's important to emphasize that any dose adjustment should be made cautiously and based on clinical monitoring, including assessing the efficacy of seizure control and watching for any potential side effects. The decision should be individualized and ideally supported by drug level monitoring if available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decrease the dose: Decreasing the dose of retigabine would be counterproductive, as the enzyme-inducing effect of phenytoin would lower the drug levels, requiring an increase rather than a decrease.

 

Option C. Stop the drug: Stopping retigabine is not advisable without a clear indication of severe side effects or failure to control seizures. Retigabine can be an effective antiepileptic, and its discontinuation should be based on clinical judgment and not just due to the addition of another drug.

 

Option D. Stop retigabine and start on carbamazepine: This option suggests switching to another antiepileptic drug. While carbamazepine is another enzyme inducer like phenytoin, switching medications is not necessary unless there are specific reasons to do so, such as intolerability or ineffectiveness of retigabine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When phenytoin, an enzyme inducer, is added to a regimen that includes retigabine, the dose of retigabine should be increased to compensate for the increased metabolism and maintain effective seizure control.

choices.text: Treatment of migraine
Treatment of Lennox Gastaut syndrome
Prophylaxis of ADHD
Treatment of dementia

questions.text: Topiramate is used for? (INICET May 2021
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Treatment of Lennox Gastaut syndrome

 

Topiramate is an antiepileptic drug that can be used for the treatment of Lennaux-Gestaut Syndrome (characterized by multifocal seizures, having <2.5 Hz spike and wave pattern in EEG). It primarily works by blocking the Na+ channels, and to some extent it also enhances the GABA receptor currents and limiting the activation of the AMPA-kainate subtype of glutamate receptors.

 

Topiramate can also be used for:

 

  • C: Decreasing the Craving of alcohol
  • O: Obesity
  • M: Migraine Prophylaxis (not treatment)
  • B: Bipolar disorder.

 

So, among the given options, best answer is Lennox Gastaut syndrome. Do not get confused with migraine as the options specifically mentions the treatment of migraine whereas topiramate is used for prophylaxis of migraine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treatment of migraine: Topiramate is used for the prophylaxis of migraines, not for the acute treatment of migraine attacks.

 

Option C. Prophylaxis of ADHD: Topiramate is not indicated for the prophylaxis or treatment of ADHD.

 

Option D. Treatment of dementia: Topiramate is not used for the treatment of dementia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Topiramate is primarily used for the treatment of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, a severe form of epilepsy in children. It is also used for the prophylaxis of migraines, reducing alcohol cravings, aiding in weight loss, and as an adjunct therapy for bipolar disorder.

choices.text: Andexanet alfa: Edoxaban
Andexanet alfa: Rivaroxaban
Idarucizumab: Dabigatran

questions.text: Which of the following is not a correct match regarding FDA approved antidotes of anticoagulants? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ciraparantag: Fondaparinux

 

FDA-approved antidotes for specific anticoagulants are designed to counteract the effects of these drugs in cases of excessive bleeding or when rapid reversal is required for surgery or other urgent medical situations.

 

Ciraparantag is a broad-spectrum antidote that has shown effectiveness against various anticoagulants, including dabigatran, oral factor Xa inhibitors, low molecular weight heparins (LMWH), unfractionated heparin (UFH), and fondaparinux. However, it is important to note that Ciraparantag is not currently FDA-approved for these indications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Andexanet alfa: Edoxaban: Andexanet alfa is an FDA-approved antidote for oral factor Xa inhibitors, including Edoxaban, Apixaban, and Rivaroxaban. It works by binding to and sequestering the factor Xa inhibitors, thus reversing their anticoagulant effects.

 

Option B. Andexanet alfa: Rivaroxaban: Similarly, Andexanet alfa is also the antidote for Rivaroxaban, a factor Xa inhibitor.

 

Option C. Idarucizumab: Dabigatran: Idarucizumab is a monoclonal antibody that specifically binds to Dabigatran, an oral direct thrombin inhibitor, and neutralizes its anticoagulant effect. This antidote is FDA-approved.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Andexanet alfa is the approved antidote for oral factor Xa inhibitors like Edoxaban and Rivaroxaban, while Idarucizumab is the antidote for Dabigatran. Although Ciraparantag has shown promise as a broad-spectrum antidote, it is not FDA-approved for use with fondaparinux or other anticoagulants.

choices.text: Labile hypertension
Pulmonary hypertension
Treatment of resistant migraine
Resistant Parkinson's disease

questions.text: Inhaled Nitric oxide is approved for treatment of? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pulmonary hypertension

 

Inhaled Nitric Oxide (NO) has specific clinical applications, particularly in the field of pulmonary medicine. It is approved for the treatment of pulmonary hypertension, especially in certain acute settings. It works by selectively dilating the pulmonary vessels by increasing cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP), thereby reducing pulmonary artery pressure and improving oxygenation. Inhaled nitric oxide is particularly noted for its use in newborns with hypoxic respiratory failure associated with pulmonary hypertension. It can also be used in the acute management of pulmonary hypertension in adults during cardiac surgery or critical care settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Labile Hypertension: Inhaled nitric oxide is not used for the treatment of labile hypertension. Hypertension is typically managed with systemic medications rather than inhaled agents.

 

Option C. Treatment of Resistant Migraine: Inhaled nitric oxide is not a standard treatment for migraines, whether typical or resistant. Migraine treatment usually involves a range of other pharmacological interventions.

 

Option D. Resistant Parkinson's Disease: There is no established role for inhaled nitric oxide in the treatment of Parkinson’s disease. Parkinson's disease management primarily involves medications that affect dopamine pathways.

 

Other uses of inhaled Nitric Oxide:

 

  • Neonatal Care: It is particularly valuable in the treatment of newborns with persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN) to improve oxygenation.
  • Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): While its benefits in ARDS in adults are still a subject of research and debate, it has been used for its pulmonary vasodilator effects in some critical care settings.
  • Cardiac Surgery: Inhaled NO can be used during cardiac surgery to control pulmonary artery pressures.
  • Lung Transplantation: It may be used to reduce pulmonary hypertension and improve graft function immediately after transplantation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhaled Nitric Oxide is approved for the treatment of pulmonary hypertension, particularly in acute settings to reduce pulmonary artery pressure and improve oxygenation. It is not used for labile hypertension, migraines, or Parkinson's disease.

choices.text: Presence of benzalkonium bromide in the preparation
Associated use of hypertonic saline in nebulizer

questions.text: All of the following can be the mechanism for paradoxical bronchoconstriction seen with the use of ipratropium bromide Except? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Prejunctional M2 receptor stimulation

 

Pre-synaptic muscarinic M2 receptors inhibit the release of acetylcholine which is a potent bronchoconstrictor. Therefore, presynaptic stimulation of these receptors will result in bronchodilation, not constriction. On the other hand, ipratropium can cause transient bronchoconstriction initially, one the reason is blockade (not stimulation) of the pre-synaptic receptors resulting in more release of acetylcholine.

 

  • Paradoxical bronchoconstriction with ipratropium bromide, particularly when given by nebulizer, were largely explained as:

    • Effects of the hypertonic nebulizer solution

    • Antibacterial additives, such as benzalkonium chloride and EDTA.

    • Presynaptic blockade (not stimulation) of muscarinic (M2) receptors

  • This problem has not been described with tiotropium bromide or other LAMAs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of benzalkonium bromide in the preparation: Benzalkonium bromide is a preservative that can cause bronchoconstriction in susceptible individuals when used in nebulized medications.

 

Option C. Associated use of hypertonic saline in nebuliser: Hypertonic saline can irritate the airways and lead to bronchoconstriction, which can explain paradoxical reactions during nebulization.

 

Option D. Presence of EDTA as impurity: EDTA, used as a stabilizing agent in some formulations, can also cause bronchoconstriction by irritating the airways

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paradoxical bronchoconstriction associated with ipratropium bromide is not caused by prejunctional M2 receptor stimulation. Instead, it can be caused by the presence of benzalkonium bromide, use of hypertonic saline, and presence of EDTA as impurities, which can all irritate the airways and lead to bronchoconstriction.

choices.text: Intra-abdominal infections

questions.text: Antimicrobial combinations are used in all except? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Gonorrhea

 

Drug of choice for treatment of gonorrhea is single dose ceftriaxone therapy. It does not require combination therapy.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. For Management of Tuberculosis, a combination of drugs consisting of Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide and Ethambutol are used. In cases like MDR or XDR TB, other drugs like Bedaquiline, Levofloxacin, Ethionamide etc. are used in various combinations and in the form of different regimens.

 

Option C. Intraabdominal infections are generally polymicrobial in nature consisting of both aerobic and anaerobic microorganisms. Combination therapy with metronidazole and other agents like ciprofloxacin, cefepime, etc. are used as empirical agents to treat them.

 

Option D. Malaria: In case of Plasmodium vivax infection, Chloroquine is used for 3 days + Primaquine is added for 14 days. For P. Falciparum infection, combination therapy consisting of ACT-SP (Artesunate + Sulfadoxine + Pyrimethamine) are used along with a single dose of Primaquine on Day 2. For P. Falciparum infection in the north eastern states, ACT-AL (Artemether + Lumefantrine) is used.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antimicrobial combination therapy is not used for the treatment of gonorrhea, which is typically managed with single-dose ceftriaxone therapy. In contrast, tuberculosis, intra-abdominal infections, and malaria require combination therapy to effectively manage the infections and prevent resistance.

choices.text: Bipolar disorder

questions.text: Which of the following is not an off-label use of risperidone? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bipolar disorder
 

Off-label drug use refers to the prescription of a medication for a condition that is not included in its approved labeling by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA).

 

Risperidone is FDA-approved for the treatment of bipolar disorder. It is specifically approved for the short-term treatment of acute manic or mixed episodes associated with Bipolar I Disorder, both as monotherapy and as an adjunct to lithium or valproate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. OCD (Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder): The use of risperidone for OCD is generally considered off-label. While antipsychotics like risperidone can be used adjunctively in treatment-resistant OCD, it's not an FDA-approved indication.

 

Option B. Dementia: Using risperidone for the treatment of behavioral symptoms in dementia is off-label. Although it's sometimes prescribed for this purpose, it's important to note that the FDA has issued a black box warning about the increased risk of death when using antipsychotic drugs in elderly patients with dementia-related psychosis.

 

Option C. PTSD: (Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder): The use of risperidone in PTSD is also off-label. It has been studied and used for managing certain symptoms of PTSD, but it is not an FDA-approved indication for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Risperidone is FDA-approved for the treatment of bipolar disorder, making it a labeled use. In contrast, the use of risperidone for OCD, dementia, and PTSD are off-label indications.

choices.text: 20.8 hours
6.9 hours
13.8 hours

questions.text: The elimination rate constant of a drug is 0.05 hr. What is its half-life? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 13.8 hours

 

  • Half-life is the time in which the plasma concentration of the drug becomes half.
  • The elimination rate constant of a drug reflects the fraction of drug that is removed from the body compartment per unit time.
  • The elimination rate constant = k = 0.05 hr.
  • Half-life = t1/2 = 0.693/k
  • Therefore t1/2 = 0.693/0.05 =13.8 hrs.
     

Educational Objective:

 

The half-life of a drug with an elimination rate constant of 0.05 hr is 13.8 hours, calculated using the formula t1/2=0.693/k

choices.text: 30 minutes
60 minutes
90 minutes

questions.text: A patient is on phenytoin for a seizure disorder. He was prescribed sucralfate 4 times a day for peptic ulcers. What should be the minimum duration of time between consumption of these drugs? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 120 minutes

 

  • Sucralfate is made up of aluminium octosulphate of sucrose. In the acidic pH of the stomach, it gets polymerized into a viscous fluid which adheres to the base of the ulcer for upto 6 hours. However, this viscous layer prevents the absorption of other drugs like phenytoin, ketoconazole, fluoroquinolones etc. from the stomach.
  • When a patient is taking both phenytoin (an antiepileptic drug) and sucralfate (a medication used to treat peptic ulcers), it's important to manage the timing of these medications to avoid drug interactions.
  • Sucralfate can interfere with the absorption of phenytoin when taken too closely together, leading to reduced effectiveness of phenytoin.
  • The general recommendation is to separate the administration of these two drugs by at least 2 hours. This separation allows sufficient time for the phenytoin to be absorbed before the sucralfate is taken, which can bind to drugs in the gastrointestinal tract and hinder their absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The minimum duration of time between the consumption of phenytoin and sucralfate should be at least 120 minutes (2 hours) to ensure that phenytoin is adequately absorbed and to avoid interactions that could reduce its effectiveness.

questions.text: Which of the following structure is affected in pancreas of a patient with Cystic Fibrosis? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

The part labelled 'B' in the image is the acini (exocrine pancreas) which is affected in cystic fibrosis.

 

 

In Cystic Fibrosis, there is accumulation mucin in ducts of pancreas which leads to atrophy of exocrine pancreas.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A: Likely corresponds to a blood vessel, which is not primarily affected in CF.

 

Option C. C: Corresponds to a larger duct, which may also be obstructed by mucus, but the question specifically asks about the structure most commonly affected, which is the acini.

 

Option D. D: May correspond to an islet of Langerhans (endocrine pancreas), which is less commonly affected in the early stages of CF compared to the exocrine acini.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Cystic Fibrosis, the acini (exocrine pancreas) are primarily affected due to mucus accumulation in the ducts, leading to atrophy and fibrosis of the exocrine pancreas.

questions.text:
A pregnant woman at 36 weeks gestation is found to have high blood pressure recording and a urine protein of 3+. Concomitant presence of which of the following symptoms would make you suspect imminent eclampsia? 

 

1. Headache

2. Blurred vision

3. Persistent pedal edema

4. Epigastric pain
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

At 36 weeks of gestation with hypertension and proteinuria, the presence of headache, blurred vision, persistent pedal edema, and epigastric pain (1, 2, 3, 4) are ominous symptoms indicative of imminent eclampsia. These symptoms reflect severe systemic effects possibly including cerebral edema, retinal injury, capillary leak syndrome, and hepatic involvement, which significantly elevate the risk of eclampsia, characterized by seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2 and 4 only: Excluding headache and pedal edema underestimates the range of symptoms associated with severe pre-eclampsia and impending eclampsia.

 

Option B. 1 and 2 only: While headache and blurred vision are significant, excluding persistent pedal edema and epigastric pain omits other critical indicators of organ involvement and systemic severity.

 

Option C. 1, 2, 3: Excluding epigastric pain ignores potential hepatic involvement, which can be a critical indicator of severe disease progression towards eclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The take-home point for students is to recognize that the presence of headache, blurred vision, persistent pedal edema, and epigastric pain in a pre-eclamptic patient are critical signs suggesting imminent eclampsia, necessitating immediate comprehensive management.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the quadruple screening test?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibin B

 

Inhibin B is not included in the quadruple screening test. The quadruple test, typically performed in the second trimester between 15-21 weeks of gestation, includes Maternal Serum AFP, hCG, Unconjugated Estriol, and Dimeric Inhibin A, not Inhibin B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Unconjugated Estriol (E3): This hormone is included in the quadruple screening test. It helps in assessing the risk of certain chromosomal conditions such as Down syndrome.

 

Option C. AFP: Alpha-fetoprotein is a key component of the quadruple screening test, used primarily to screen for neural tube defects and abdominal wall defects.

 

Option D. hCG: Human chorionic gonadotropin is also a part of the quadruple screening, important for evaluating the risk of chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The take-home point for students is to accurately identify the components of the quadruple screening test, which are AFP, hCG, Unconjugated Estriol, and Dimeric Inhibin A. It’s essential to distinguish between Dimeric Inhibin A and Inhibin B, as only the former is included in the test, reflecting a specific protocol used in prenatal screening for chromosomal abnormalities.
